dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woodlands.  Beautiful.  Untamed.  Soaring old-growth elms arch over riverside maples along the shores of the gently curving, deep-water Santee River.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April, 1776

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upstream, the swamps.  Beautiful.  Hundreds of BIRDS SING Shafts of sunlight pierce the canopy, cutting through the hanging moss and kudzu, falling onto soft, swaying ferns covering the high ground. The water is clear, with fields of floating lily pads, each with a stark white flower rising from it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A farm built between the banks of the river and the deep green of the swamps.  Good, fertile land, hacked out of the wilderness. The perfectly tended fields are ripe with barley, hops, alfalfa and tobacco.  Two sturdy brothers, NATHAN, 13 and SAMUEL, 12, work one of the fields, rhythmically swinging scythes through the barley. The house, built of native brick, is well-constructed and well-maintained.  There's a barn, a workshop and a forge. It is a home of substance rather than wealth.  On the front porch, MARGARET, 11, pumps a butter churn while her brother, WILLIAM, 6, watches. GABRIEL, 18, strong and handsome, walks out of the woods with a musket in his hand and a dozen game-birds over his shoulder.  At his side walks THOMAS, 14, also carrying a musket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A perfect colonial workshop, fastidiously arranged with every conceivable tool of the period.  A foot-powered lathe.  A drop-forge.  A lifting saw.  Racks of tools, planes, hammers, augers, drills, blocks, all hanging in their places.  All very well-worn. FRANCIS MARION methodically works his lathe, turning a piece of hardwood, shaving off tiny curls of wood with a razor-sharp chisel.  He's in his late-forties, strong and weathered.  His hands, though big and callused, handle th chisel with a surgeon's precision.  Self-educated and self-sufficient, he has built himself, as he built his farm, brick by brick, from the coarse clay of the earth. A finely-made rocking chair, missing only the dowel on which Marion is working, sits on the work table.  The chair is a work of art, thin and light, a spider-web of perfectly turned wood, no nails, no glue. Sitting on the woodpile, SUSAN, 4, a silent, stone-face wisp of a child, watches her father. Marion takes the piece of wood out of the lathe, carefull fits it into the chair, inserts a peg and taps it into place.  Then he steps back and appraises his handiwork. He picks up the chair and hooks the top rail to a scale, countering with a three-pound weight.  The chair floats. Marion blows softly on the weight which sinks.  Susan nods, so far, so good.  Marion puts the chair on the floo and walks slowly around it, checking every angle. Then, the acid test.  He takes a deep breath and lowers himself onto the seat, gingerly adding an ounce at a time Not a creak.  He smiles and sits back with a sigh. CRACK!  THE CHAIR SPLINTERS under Marion's weight, DUMPIN HIM on his ass on a pile of broken wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damnation! He picks up some of the wood, about to fling it across th room but stops as Susan shoots him a disapproving look. He calms himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. Susan gets down from the woodpile and puts the remains of the chair in the fireplace.  As she climbs back up to her perch, Marion steps over to his wood rack, extracts a fresh dowel, fits it into the lathe and starts all over again. END CREDITS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion leaves the workshop with Susan at his side.  Natha and Samuel walk past, exhausted from their day in the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, I saw a post rider at the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  Did you finish the upper field?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got it all cut and we bundled half of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those swimming breaks cut into the day, don't they? Marion walks on without waiting for a reply from his contrite sons who jostle one another, trying to pass off the blame.  Gabriel and Thomas walk out of the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, a post rider came from Charleston.  You have a letter inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  How's the spotted one's milk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better.  She's near ready to calve. Marion nods and motions for Susan to go with Gabriel and Thomas to the house.  She does so and Marion walks on alone toward:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The loveliest spot on the farm.  A beautiful view of the house, barns, river, fields and hills beyond.  A gravestone stands in the shade of a single apple tree.  I reads:

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH PUTNAM MARION 1738-1773
dialogues.text: Above her name is a carving of the night sky, at the center of which is the NORTH STAR, steady and guiding. Marion approaches.  He gives himself a moment to look at the grave, then he starts picking apples, speaking to the gravestone in a quiet voice that is more matter-of-fact than sorrowful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and they bundled half... almost no trace of the boys you knew... A soft wind blows some dry leaves along the ground. Marion pauses as if listening to a spoken reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... no, she still hasn't spoken... Margaret was her age when you... I remember the time at the river when we couldn't find Catherine... you couldn't stop crying... and she was asleep in the wagon the entire time... Marion pauses, remembering.  The CRASH OF A PLATE BREAKING, followed by the SOUND OF AN ARGUMENT rises from the house below.  Marion shakes his head with an exasperated sigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your children. He heads down the hill toward the house, now glowing from the lights of candles and oil lamps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pre-dinner chaos.  Everyone talking at once.  Marion's seven children and his two family servants, ABIGAIL and AARON, a middle-aged black couple, prepare dinner.  Susan silently watches from the stairs.  Marion walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I smell turnips...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, Samuel broke the blue plate...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did not...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner... Marion hands the apples to Abigail and steps over to open his mail and dispatches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: News of Boston, father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate turnips...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William knocked it right out of my hands...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel, William, both of you clean it up... Marion hands a packet of pamphlets to Gabriel and opens a letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Assembly has been reconvened, I've been called to... Marion's children go wild.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charleston!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to Charleston!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When, father, when?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll leave tomorrow... The children ERUPT INTO CHEERS and THUNDER into the dinin room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charleston!  We're going to Charleston! Marion and Gabriel exchange a stone-faced look.  Then Marion puts on a smile and inhales deeply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love turnips... Marion follows his children into the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet.  The only sounds are the soft calls of a few NIGHTBIRDS and the DRONE OF CICADAS.  A faint light moves through the downstairs, passing windows in the otherwise dark house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion, holding a candle, does a father's bedtime check. The CAMERA FOLLOWS him as he makes his rounds into: THE KITCHEN.  Everything is clean and put away in its proper place. THE MAIN HALLWAY.  Marion checks that the doors are close and bolted.  He heads up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion enters, finding William asleep on the floor and Nathan and Samuel in bed.  He lifts William into bed, takes a slingshot from Nathan's hand, tucks in Samuel and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion steps to the doorway, finding Margaret and Susan a the window, looking up at the night sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... now count five finger lengths up from the front two stars of the Big Dipper, and that's the North Star, that's her. Susan gazes up at the North Star.  The girls notice Mario and climb into bed.  He puts a chair against Susan's bed and kisses her.  He pulls a blanket up around Margaret, who whispers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It helps her to know Mother's there. Marion nods with a thin smile, kisses Margaret and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Squadrons of lead soldiers stand ready for battle as Thomas, lying on the floor, deploys his men.  Gabriel reads the new pamphlets and broadsides.  Marion walks in and pours a drink.  Gabriel hands several of the pamphlet to his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The New York and Rhode Island assemblies have been dissolved...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The middle colonies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rioting both sides of the bay, in Chestertown they burned the Customs House and tar-and-feathered the Customs Agent.  He died of burns. In Wilmington they killed a Royal Magistrate and two Redcoats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything about the convention in Philadelphia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor Richard says they'll make a Declaration of Independence by July. Marion shakes his head and sits down, carefully extractin a delicate pair of reading glasses from a wooden box.  He begins reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott Higgins joined the militia. Marion hears but doesn't respond.  Thomas looks up from his lead soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's seventeen.  A year younger than I. Gabriel and Thomas wait for a reaction.  There is none. Gabriel goes back to reading and Thomas resumes playing with his toy soldiers.  Marion's eyes drift from the page to Gabriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Marion family, in two tightly-packed carriages, drive on a beautiful road, cut through the swamps.  The canopy of swamp maples and weeping willows forms a tunnel of green, mottled by sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two carriages pass a view of their entire valley. Scattered farms with a patchwork of cultivated fields surrounding the town of Bennington.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passing through rolling farmland, the Marions head toward the coast.  They pass a large contingent of South Carolin Militia, drilling in a field.  The children, particularly Gabriel, watch avidly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big, bustling city.  Marion and Gabriel negotiate the carriages through the busy streets.  The children watch, wide-eyed, seeing taverns, a public gallows, drunkards, street entertainers, well-dressed ladies attended by thei maids, food venders, a man with a trained bear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grand.  Four stories.  Marion and his children pull up. CHARLOTTE MOTTE hurries out.  She's in her mid-thirties, beautiful, with a deep sadness that she keeps hidden as best she can. The children leap from the carriages and swarm around her embracing her, smothering her with kisses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aunt Charlotte!  Aunt Charlotte!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome!  Welcome!  Margaret, William, look at you...! (to Marion)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're huge.  What have you been feeding them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're from good stock on their mother's side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Charlotte hustles the children toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, come, inside, wait until you see what I have...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simultaneous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Presents!  For me?  What do you have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, inside... Charlotte sweeps past Marion who smiles and follows her into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion watches as Charlotte finishes handing out presents Susan plays with a new doll.  William has half-a-dozen ne spinning tops, skimming around the floor.  Margaret holds a new dress up to herself.  Samuel, Nathan and Thomas tea into packages holding platoons of lead soldiers.  Gabriel looks through a new book. Charlotte sees Marion watching her, rises and joins him a the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look well, Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As do you. Suddenly Thomas and Samuel race through the doorway, forcing Marion and Charlotte together, their bodies close They step back and exchange warm but uneasy smiles. The moment is broken by the SOUND OF CHILDREN.  Marion an Charlotte gratefully turn their attention back to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down the block from the Motte house.  A yelling crowd of Sons of Liberty is massed around a Liberty Tree from whic hang dozens of glowing lanterns.  Most of the men in the crowd are drunk.  Vendors sell rum, ale, food and banners emblazoned with a coiled snake and the legend, "Don't Tread On Me."  Scores of on-lookers, including respectabl people, as well as street urchins, whores and drunkards, watch the proceedings. Several Sons of Liberty string up effigies of King George III and Governor Wilmington.  They light the effigies on fire.  As they begin to blaze, the crowd cheers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion's children, except Gabriel, stand on the balcony watching the mob.  Marion steps out onto the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, all of you... The children turn to Marion with stricken expressions. Marion relents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well. The children turn back to the mob.  Marion joins them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look!  There's Gabriel! They see Gabriel making his way through the crowd.  He sees them and waves, then enters the house. A moment later Charlotte steps out onto the balcony and sees: IN THE SQUARE, a pair of drunk Sons of Liberty, pull down one of the smoldering effigies, cut off its head, then start hacking at it's groin with a sword. Appalled, Charlotte shoots a glare at Marion and snaps at the children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Children, inside!  All of you! Right now. The children start to protest, but a glance at Charlotte' resolute expression makes them think better of it.  They file into the house.  Charlotte shoots a glare at Marion and shoos the children inside.  Gabriel steps out and joins them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What news?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The British army is barricaded in Boston.  Harry Lee, is here from Virginia, recruiting for a Continental Army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that why the Assembly was convened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  He seeks a levy of troops and money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the Governor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He vowed that if the Assembly votes a single shilling to Lee, he'll dissolve the body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which would force our delegates in Philadelphia to vote for independence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And send us to war alongside Massachusetts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our governor is a bigger fool than I thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lee is counting on your vote and expects you to be the first to enlist. Marion nods thoughtfully without revealing what he thinks of Lee's expectations.  Marion turns back to watch the mob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The capital building of South Carolina.  A large crowd of lower-class men and women is massed in front of the Assembly Hall.  As well-dressed Assemblymen walk into the building, the CROWD YELLS words of encouragement to some and berates others. In the square in front of the Assembly Hall a squadron of blue-uniformed AMERICAN CONTINENTAL SOLDIERS drills.  A recruiting table is being set up by a Continental Captain and several military clerks. Marion and Gabriel walk across the square toward the Assembly Hall.  As they push their way through the crowd, Gabriel eyes the Continentals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two dozen ANGRY, YELLING, MEN OF PROPERTY.  Among them ar ROBINSON, HAMILL and JOHNSON, who are Patriots.  Opposed to them are SIMMS, WITHINGTON and BALDRIDGE who are Loyalists (loyal the the King).  As Marion makes his way to his seat, the SPEAKER OF THE ASSEMBLY POUNDS HIS GAVEL

dialogues.speaker: ORDER
dialogues.text: Slowly, the room quiets down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our first order of business...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And out last if we vote a levy... The ROOM ERUPTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ORDER!  ORDER!  Mr. Simms, you do not have the floor. The ROOM SETTLES DOWN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our first order of business is an address by Colonel Harry Lee of the Continental Army. An imposing figure rises and makes his way to the front o the assembly.  He's COLONEL HARRY LEE, about Marion's age and cut from the same cloth -- strong, weathered, with a powerful bearing.  The room quiets down. Lee sees Marion and offers a familiar nod, which Marion returns, stone-faced.  Then Lee speaks, simply and clearly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all know why I am here.  I am not an orator and I will not try to convince you of the worthiness of our cause.  I am a soldier and we are at war and with the declaration of independence we all expect from Philadelphia, it will soon be a formal state of war.  In preparation for that, eight of the thirteen colonies have levied money in support of a Continental Army.  I ask South Carolina to be the ninth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Lee, Massachusetts may be at war, along with New Hampshire and Rhode Island and Virginia, but South Carolina is not at war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Massachusetts and New Hampshire are not as far from South Carolina as you might think and the war they're fighting is not for independence of one or two colonies.  It's for the independence of a nation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what nation is that? Robinson, one of the Patriots, stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An American nation.  Colonel Lee, with your permission?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those of us who call ourselves Patriots are not seeking to give birth to an American nation, but to protect one that already exists.  It was born a hundred-and-seventy years ago at Jamestown, Virginia and has grown stronger and more mature with every generation reared and with every crop sown and harvested.  We are a nation and our rights as citizens of that nation are threatened by a tyrant three thousand miles away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  Were I an orator, those are the exact words I would have spoken. Laughter.  Marion rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Robinson, tell me, why should I trade one tyrant, three thousand miles away, for three thousand tyrants, one mile away? Laughter from the Loyalists.  Surprise from Lee and the Patriots.  In the gallery, Gabriel winces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An elected legislature can trample a man's rights just as easily as a King can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Marion, I understood you to be a Patriot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Mister Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understood him to be a Patriot as well. More laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you mean by a Patriot, am I angry at the Townsend Acts and the Stamp Act?  Then I'm a Patriot.  And what of the Navigation Act?  Should I be permitted to sell my tobacco to the French traders on Martinique?  Yes, and it's an intrusion into my affairs that I can't... legally. Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what of the greedy, self-serving bastards who sit as Magistrates on the Admiralty Court and have fined nearly every man in this room. Should they be boxed about the ears and thrown onto the first ship back to England?  I'll do it myself. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And do I believe that the American colonies should stand as a separate, independent nation, free from the reins of King and Parliament?  I do, and if that makes a Patriot, then I'm a Patriot. Marion grows more serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if you're asking whether I'm willing to go to war with England, the answer is, no.  I've been to war and I have no desire to do so again. The room is quiet, the Assemblymen having been thrown off balance.  Gabriel is stunned and disappointed by his father's speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This from the same Captain Francis Marion whose anger was so famous during the Wilderness Campaign. Marion glares at Robinson, then smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was intemperate in my youth.  My departed wife, God bless her soul, dampened that intemperance with the mantle of responsibility. Robinson looks derisively at Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Temperance can be a convenient disguise for fear. Marion bristles but before he can answer, Lee steps in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Robinson, I fought with Captain Marion in the French and Indian War, including the Wilderness Campaign.  We served as scouts under Washington and I have no doubts about Captain Marion's courage or competence on a battlefield. There's not a man in this room, or anywhere, for that matter, to whom I would more willingly trust my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stand corrected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonetheless, I would like to know, Mister Marion, how... how... how... Lee's oratorical skills peter out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn it, Francis!  How in God's name do you expect to gain independence without going to war?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, Harry, Harry... Marion and Lee drop all formality and become nothing more than two old friends, pissed off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My hairy arse!  You live in a cave if you think we'll get independence without war... The Speaker POUNDS HIS GAVEL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen!  Please!  This is not a tavern!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't it a Union Jack we fought under?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long time ago...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirteen years...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a damn long time... The Speaker POUNDS HIS GAVEL again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen!  Please! Marion and Lee ignore the speaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were an Englishman then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was an American, I just didn't know it yet... The astonished Assemblymen and now even the Speaker watch the argument avidly, turning their heads in simultaneous anticipation of each rejoinder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have to go to war to gain independence...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Balderdash!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are a thousand avenues, other than war, at our disposal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name five hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Royal petition, delegates to court, judicial redress, economic boycott, bribery...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's five, keep going...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... time, royal succession, regicide, bribery...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said bribery twice... Marion speaks slowly and firmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do not have to go to war to gain independence. Lee says nothing for a moment, then he speaks more seriously, quietly, grimly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francis, I was at Bunker Hill.  It was as bad as anything you and I saw on the frontier.  Worse than the slaughter at the Ashuelot River. The British advanced three times and we killed over seven hundred of them at point blank range.  And still, they advanced and they took the ground.  That is the measure of their resolve.  If your principles dictate independence, then war is the only way.  It has come to that. Marion is silent for a long moment.  He softens, finds himself unsteady and speaks far more honestly than he eve wanted to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have seven children.  My wife is dead.  Who's to care for them if I go to war? Lee is stunned by Marion's honesty and his show of weakness.  At first Lee has no answer, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wars are not fought only by childless men.  A man must weigh his personal responsibilities against his principles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I'm doing.  I will not fight and because I won't, I will not cast a vote that will send others to fight in my stead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your principles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a parent, I don't have the luxury of principles. The other Assemblymen, both Patriots and Loyalists, stare at him, appalled.  Marion, feeling weak, sits down.  Lee looks at his friend with more sympathy than disappointment.  Then Lee turns to Robinson who addresses the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Speaker, I call for a vote on a levy to the Continental Army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So moved. The vote is taken on a roll call.  Gabriel watches from the gallery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Robinson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Hamill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Simms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Marion. No response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay. In the gallery Gabriel turns and walks out.  The roll cal continues.  Marion sits, eyes straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd waits.  The doors open and a PAGE BOY dashes ou and runs to the Continental Captain at the recruiting table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-eight to twelve, the levy passed! The Continental Captain motions to an assembled squadron. They raise their muskets and FIRE A VOLLEY into the air. Other soldiers, STRIKE UP A MARTIAL AIR ON FIFES AND DRUMS.  Volunteers crowd around the recruiting table, YELLING and jostling for position. The delegates walk out.  Both Patriots and Loyalists give Marion a wide berth. Marion sees Gabriel, standing near the crowd at the recruiting table.  Marion walks up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, I've lost respect for you. I thought you were a man of principle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you have children, I hope you'll understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I have children, I hope I don't hide behind them. Marion looks closely at Gabriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you intend to enlist without my permission?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. They lock eyes for a moment, then Gabriel turns from his father and walks away, joining the crush around the recruiting table. Marion stands alone in the middle of the chaos.  The FIFE AND DRUMS continue to play.  Marion doesn't hear them. Harry Lee walks out of the Assembly hall with a triumphan group of Patriots who look at Marion coldly. Lee excuses himself, and steps over next to Marion.  Lee sees that Marion is watching Gabriel at the enlistment table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I recognize him now.  Is he as imprudent as his father was at his age?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank the Lord.  He's more like his mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see to it that he serves under me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. They shake hands.  Then Lee walks over to the soldiers. Marion takes a last look at Gabriel, then heads off through the crowded square, moving against the tide of me headed toward the recruiting table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Springtime.  The apple tree at the top of the hill is covered with blossoms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion plows a field.  Nathan leads the plowhorse.  Samue follows, breaking up the clods of dirt.  Hard work.  They stop to catch their breath.  A SOFT WIND blows. Marion turns his head as if listening for a faint voice. He hears nothing.  He snaps the reins and continues plowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark.  Thomas steps up into the attic.  He finds a trunk and opens it.  Lifting out some blankets, he uncovers a trove of Marion's old military gear -- a worn battle coat a box of medals, a military sword, rusted into its scabbard. Thomas puts on the coat, which hangs off his narrow shoulders.  He stands in front of a dusty mirror, appraising himself, then stops as he hears FOOTSTEPS coming up the stairs. It's Marion, tired and dirty from his plowing.  Thomas grimaces, expecting him to be angry, but sees him shake his head gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet, Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When? Marion looks closely at his son, giving him the courtesy of really thinking about the answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventeen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's already been two years and that's two more years.  The war could be over by then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God willing. Thomas considers it, then nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.  Seventeen. Marion offers his hand.  They shake firmly, like adults. Marion takes the coat off Thomas and puts it back in the trunk.  They walk down the stairs together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All is quiet.  A dawn mist hovers close over the ground. Some sparrows feed at the base of the apple tree near the gravesite.  DISTANT THUNDER.  Low and rolling.  The birds stop feeding, uneasy, then fly away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At another roll of the DISTANT THUNDER Marion awakes.  He gets out of bed and pulls on his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion steps out to his front porch and listens.  He know the sound, the DISTANT STACCATO BOOMS OF CANNON and the PATTERING WAVE OF THOUSANDS OF MUSKETS FIRING. One by one the children join him.  Thomas, Nathan and Samuel listen analytically.  Margaret and Susan press close against their father.  William looks curiously at the cloudless sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it going to rain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not thunder. The SOUND BECOMES DEEPER, MORE OMINOUS.  They all notice the change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six-pounders.  Lots of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four, five miles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waxhaus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just east of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we safe here? Marion puts on a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could go stay at Aunt Charlotte's farm.  She's to the west.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, there'll be skirmishers on the roads.  We're safer here. Thomas appears at the doorway with a pair of muskets.  He gives one to Nathan and offers the other to his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put those away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But father, they might come this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put them away. Reluctantly, Thomas takes the muskets back into the house

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough.  I'll be in the workshop. Samuel, the cows.  Thomas, attend to your studies here on the porch. Nathan, on the back porch.  If you see anyone, come get me.  Margaret, please keep William close to you. No one is to go past the yard wall. They all nod.  Marion walks off toward the workshop, followed by Susan.  The others hesitate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Children. They head off to do as they were told.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion works the lathe.  Susan watches from her perch on the woodpile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND OF A CRASH from inside the barn.  An angry cow runs out of the barn, dragging a tenacious Samuel who is holding onto the cow's neck. Samuel's grip fails and he lands in the dirt.  The cow runs about thirty yards down the hill, stopping on the bank of the river.  Samuel grabs a rope and heads down th hill to get the cow.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE RIVERBANK
dialogues.text: As Samuel approaches the cow, he see it skittishly approaching then retreating from the water.  Then he sees the cause -- the water in the river has a pale, pink hue. Samuel stares at it, trying to figure out what it is. Behind him, Margaret sees her brother beyond the yard wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel... He doesn't respond.  Margaret, trailed by William, walks down toward Samuel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel, get up to the house.  You heard father... Then she sees it, too.  The pale pink is turning redder and redder.  And then the BODIES.  First one, then more, many more.  Torn apart.  Missing limbs.  Those with wide- open wounds, are already drained of blood.  Others are still seeping, leaving trails of deep red in the paler re of the surrounding water. Samuel, Margaret and William stand frozen, appalled and fascinated. MARION steps out of the workshop and sees the children at the river.  He can't see what they're looking at. Irritated, he walks toward them.  Then, as he nears the river, he sees the color of the water and the bodies that have hypnotized his children.  He quickens his stride, speaking calmly but firmly, careful not to frighten them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up to the house, now.  All of you, come on.  Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet.  Dark.  Marion stands on the front porch, looking out into the night, listening, hearing nothing.  He glances up at the star-filled sky, tracking his eyes from the Big Dipper to the NORTH STAR. BEHIND THE HOUSE, A FIGURE IN THE DARKNESS, carrying a musket, moves from shadow to shadow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret and Samuel and William talk, their voices low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're going to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to have to fight them off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father will do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll probably kill us men and do Lord knows what to you women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel! A SOUND.  They all stop.  Something moved behind the kitchen.  Margaret silently eases the others out of the room, through the darkened hall toward their father.

dialogues.speaker: SUDDENLY IN FRONT OF THEM, A BLOODY FIGURE
dialogues.text: Big.  Hulking.  In uniform.  Margaret SCREAMS.  William and Samuel CRY OUT.  The figure moves toward them... Marion, on the porch, hears the scream, races into the house.  He sees the figure, moves toward it... THE FIGURE MOVES INTO THE LIGHT... Marion sees the bloodied face...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel! Gabriel is wounded, battered and dirty.  He carries a musket and a dispatch case.  He sways.  Marion catches hi and eases him to a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The battle, were you there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret, get bandages and water. Thomas, the porch, eyes open. Marion checks Gabriel's wounds which are nasty but not life-threatening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you seen any Redcoats?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet.  What happened? Margaret brings water and linen to Marion who expertly cleans Gabriel's wounds and applies field-dressings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't like Saratoga.  There, we stayed in the trees, but this time Gates marched us straight at the Redcoats.  They fired two volleys into us and we broke like straw.  I was given these dispatches... I saw Virginia Regulars surrender... as they laid down their weapons the British Green Dragoons rode into them and hacked them to bits... killed them all, over two hundred men. Marion's appalled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They had surrendered? Gabriel nods.  Marion's stunned.  Gabriel tries to rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to get these dispatches to Hillsboro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in no condition to ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no choice, I... Gabriel passes out.  Marion catches him and carries him t a day-bed in the parlor.  As Marion lays him down, they hear HEAVY MUSKET FIRE, VERY CLOSE. Marion hurries to the door and looks out into the night, the children cluster around him, seeing a strange sight.

dialogues.speaker: A SKIRMISH IN THE FIELD BELOW THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Pitch black.  Then a MUSKET FIRES, creating a FLASH OF LIGHT that illuminates a tableau of soldiers, about three dozen Redcoats and as many Patriots. The strobe of the musket shot provides targets for an ensuing VOLLEY OF SHOTS in every direction.  Then darkness, punctuated by SCREAMS OF PAIN, CONFUSED HOLLERING and the RUSTLING OF ARMED MEN IN MOVEMENT. Then the pattern repeats itself:  A MUSKET FIRES, illuminating a tableau of targets for another MURDEROUS VOLLEY OF SHOTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret, take William and Susan down to the root cellar.  Thomas, go to the back porch.  Nathan and Samuel, the side windows.  Keep out of sight. They hurry off.  Marion steps into the house and opens hi gun cabinet.  He extracts two pistols and a pair of muskets.  Then he steps back to the front door.  He waits and watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First light.  The morning mist lies low over the field. Marion warily approaches the scene of the battle.  He carries a Pennsylvania rifle, has another slung over his shoulder, and has a pair of pistols in his belt. As Marion nears the field he sees, appearing out of the low mist, a nightmarish vision.  Young Redcoats and Continentals are scattered on the ground, dead and wounded.  Many have been hideously torn apart by the massive musket balls.  Blood is everywhere.  Marion hurries back toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion loads the wounded men onto a wagon, helped by Thomas, Nathan and Samuel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The porch and yard have been turned into a field hospital There are about two dozen wounded, a few more Patriots than Redcoats.  Thomas, Nathan, Samuel and Margaret help Marion tend the soldiers.  William and Susan watch from inside. Marion treats an arm wound, retying a tourniquet, stanching an ugly flow of blood. Marion moves to the next of the wounded.  Thomas starts t help but Marion shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dead... Marion moves on to another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas, help me turn him over... They turn over a young Continental and see a horrible wound on his back.  Thomas, swoons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas! A hard glare from Marion strengthens his son.  Together they bandage the wounded man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Triage completed.  Margaret and Samuel give water and food.  Marion kneels next to a CONTINENTAL SERGEANT and a COUPLE OF PRIVATES who are less severely wounded than the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Marion nods, uncomfortable with the thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant, there are seventeen wounded men here.  Seven Redcoats and ten Patriots, counting my son inside.  That puts me in a difficult position. The Continental Sergeant knows what's coming.  The Privates and Marion's children don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You three are the least severely wounded.  I have to ask you to leave and find care elsewhere. The Privates are stunned at the request.  The Sergeant looks at Marion's children and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand. He struggles to his feet and jerks his head for the two Privates to do the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, boys. Nathan, Samuel and Margaret are confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they're wounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are rules, even in war. Marion motions to a large, old scar on his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the Battle of Ashuelot River, against the French, I got this and the one on my leg.  I couldn't walk. Washington had to march north.  He left me with other wounded men and a like number of French prisoners. Nine for nine.  When the French found us, their surgeon gave me the best of care.  We'll be safe this way. Marion's children are not convinced.  The Sergeant and th two Privates gather themselves to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your best chance is in Bennington, seven miles east, along the river road. The wounded men nod grimly and start off down the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Marion and his children watch them go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dirt road runs along the edge of the Santee Swamps, stretching toward green, rolling hills beyond.  Beautiful country.  Peaceful.  Then, the GROUND BEGINS TO SHAKE.  A THUNDEROUS SOUND rises, louder and louder.  HORSES HOOVES From around a bend, a detachment of cavalry gallops: British GREEN DRAGOONS.  The finest light calvary in the world.  Hard, strong men.  Excellent horsemen.  Their mounts are powerful, muscled and perfectly cared for.  Th Dragoons themselves are all hardened veterans, marked wit the blood and dirt of a recent battle.  Tired and vigorous. They're armed to the teeth.  Each carries a flintlock carbine, a brace of pistols and a sword.  Some carry lances as well.  Regimental flags flutter.  They are fort of the most imposing, frightening horsemen imaginable. And at their head, the most imposing man of all, LT. COLONEL BANASTRE TARLETON.  "The Butcher."  Aristocratic. Strong.  Dark.  A powerful horseman on the best mount of the entire troop.  Decorated.  Imperious.  No temper, jus hard, cold authority.  His men struggle to keep up with him. Behind them, two dozen LOYALIST MILITIA CALVARY (American civilians loyal to the crown).  Nasty, local men. Civilian clothes.  Riding at their head is AMOS GASKINS, grizzled, lower-class, wearing ill-fitting patrician's clothing.

dialogues.speaker: AROUND A BEND
dialogues.text: The three wounded Patriots who just left Marion's farm hear the horses coming, stand on the side of the road, raise their arms and a white cloth of surrender. The Green Dragoons rein in.  Tarleton stops in front of the three men.  He motions for one of his men to lower hi weapon.  Then he speaks calmly, quietly, to the wounded men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're surrendering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What unit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First Virginia Regulars under Colonel Hamilton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who cared for your wounds? They hesitate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a lace table cloth? Tarleton turns to his second-in-command, MAJOR WILKINS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill them. Tarleton rides off.  Wilkins and several other Dragoons calmly FIRE THEIR PISTOLS, killing the three Patriots. The troops ride off, thundering past the bodies of the three men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion and his children tend the wounded.  Gabriel, weak but walking, helps.  REDCOAT INFANTRY appears out of the woods, heading toward the house.  Three dozen men.  Scout and flank units covering the main body.  Marion gathers his family around him, stands and waits. The Redcoats get to the house, warily eye the wounded and Marion's family.  A young REDCOAT LIEUTENANT motions his men to check out the house and barn, then looks at the wounded, doing a silent count.  He turns to Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These men are of my regiment.  Thank you. Marion nods.  ONE OF THE REDCOATS emerges from the house carrying Gabriel's dispatch case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebel dispatches, sir. Gabriel steps up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I carried those.  I was wounded, these people gave me care, they have nothing to do with the dispatches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand. The SOUND OF HORSES HOOVES.  All turn and see:

dialogues.speaker: TARLETON AND THE GREEN DRAGOONS
dialogues.text: Thundering down the road toward the house.  It's an impressive, frightening sight. They rein in their horses, stopping in the yard, envelope by their trailing cloud of dust. Tarleton surveys the scene, then speaks to the young Redcoat Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant, have a detachment take our wounded to our surgeons at Camden crossing.  Use whatever horses and wagons you can find here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. He hands the dispatch case to Tarleton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We found this, sir. Tarleton opens it and quickly scans the contents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who carried this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lt. re: Gabriel)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take this one to Camden, he's a spy. He will be hung. Marion quickly steps between Tarleton and Gabriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel, he's a dispatch rider and that's a marked dispatch case. Tarleton ignores Marion and continues speaking to the Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire the house and barns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the Rebel wounded?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill them. The Redcoat Lieutenant and several of his men are shocked by the order.  Marion is, also, but he's more concerned with Gabriel.  He pushes past some Redcoats and stands at Tarleton's mount, looking up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dispatch rider with a marked case cannot be held for spying. Tarleton finally pays attention to Marion.  He looks down at his anguished face and offers the barest of smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not going to hold him, we're going to hang him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... Tarleton draws his pistol and points it at Marion. Gabriel tries to intercede but is held back by a burly Redcoat Corporal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, he's your son.  You should have taught him about loyalty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel, I beg you, please reconsider.  By the rules of war, a dispatch rider with a marked case... Tarleton controls his shifting mount, keeping his pistol trained on Marion's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like a lesson in the rules of war? Marion doesn't answer.  He looks up at Tarleton coldly, taking his measure, waiting to see if he's going to pull the trigger. Tarleton walks his horse a couple of steps and shifts his aim, pointing the pistol among Marion's children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps your children would. The children are terrified.  Thomas is more angry than frightened.  Marion quickly steps between the pistol and his children and speaks quietly to Tarleton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No lesson is necessary. Tarleton sees the terrified expressions on the faces of Marion's children.  He smiles at the effect.  Then he holsters his pistol. Marion and his children watch as one of the Redcoats ties Gabriel's hands.  Thomas is beside himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, do something. Thomas grows increasingly agitated.  He sees that his father is going to do nothing.  He gauges the distance between Gabriel and the cover of the nearby woods. Then suddenly, Thomas SPRINGS.  He RUNS, THROWING HIMSELF into the two Redcoats holding Gabriel, KNOCKING THEM DOWN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel!  Run! Gabriel is too shocked to take flight.  A few of the Redcoats, including one of the ones knocked down, shake their heads with sad laughter at Thomas' ineffectual gesture.  One of them grabs Thomas by the scruff of the neck and yanks him to his feet. TARLETON sees the commotion.  Without pausing he DRAWS HI PISTOL AND FIRES, HITTING THOMAS IN THE BACK. THOMAS is thrown to his knees by the shot.  Stunned, confused, he looks down and sees the massive exit wound i his chest. MARION, horrified, catches Thomas as he falls, easing him to the ground. MARGARET CRIES OUT.  THE OTHER CHILDREN are stunned to silence. The REDCOATS are frozen in place.  Tarleton's GREEN DRAGOONS are impassive, having seen worse. MARION holds his son, looking at the huge, incomprehensible wound.  He knows that Thomas is already dead, though his body still moves. MARION'S stunned agony turns to fury.  He rises, his eyes trained on Tarleton, then stops as... TARLETON raises a second loaded pistol and a DOZEN GREEN DRAGOONS raise pistols and carbines, aiming them at Mario and his children. MARION FREEZES, torn between his fury and fear for his other children.  He locks his eyes on Tarleton. TARLETON calmly baths in Marion's anger.  Then, with a hard yank of the reins, he jerks his horse's head around and utters a sharp command to Wilkins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major. Tarleton spurs his horse and rides off without looking back.  His GREEN DRAGOONS THUNDER after him. MARION'S CHILDREN begin to cry.  Margaret tries to revive Thomas' lifeless body, gently caressing his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas, please, Thomas... The Redcoats watch in silence.  MARION LOOKS AT GABRIEL and turns to the Redcoat Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant, please... The Lieutenant wavers, but he looks after the departing Tarleton and his resolve stiffens.  He turns coldly to Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have my orders.  Sergeant! The Redcoat infantrymen scatter, some to get horses and wagons from the barn, others to torch the buildings. MARION stands among the children, all of whom look to Marion with pleading eyes, waiting for him to do something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa, look what they did to Thomas...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, they're going to take Gabriel... With stone-faced fury, Marion watches the Redcoats do their work. From the barns, they hear the sounds of MUSKETS FIRING an the SQUEALS OF THE LIVESTOCK being killed. Other REDCOATS TORCH THE HOUSE, BARN AND OUTBUILDINGS. THE FLAMES RISE. The Redcoats bring out Marion's wagons and carriages and begin loading the Redcoat wounded. The Redcoat Lieutenant and several of his men walk among the Patriot wounded who start to struggle to their feet, begging for mercy.  The Redcoats quickly OPEN FIRE, as if to get it over with. The WOUNDED PATRIOTS CRY OUT.  More SHOTS.  Then SILENCE. GABRIEL, his hands bound behind him, looks to his father with a combination of resoluteness and fear.  Marion lock eyes with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, you can't let them take him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet.

dialogues.speaker: MARION AND THE CHILDREN
dialogues.text: Watch as the Redcoats form up and move out, leading Gabriel on a tether.  Gabriel looks back helplessly but a hard jerk on the rope by one of the Redcoats turns him around.  They disappear around a bend in the road. THE INSTANT THE REDCOATS ARE OUT OF SIGHT, MARION speaks firmly to his weeping children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't move. MARION STRIDES to his front door and ENTERS THE BURNING HOUSE. INSIDE, FIRE EVERYWHERE.  Picking a route between the flames, Marion walks to his gun cabinet.  He opens it and pulls out weapons -- two Pennsylvania rifles, two muskets two pistols, a long-bladed knife and a worn tomahawk.  He carries them, with powder horns and ammunition pouches back toward the door. Marion walks OUT OF THE BURNING HOUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan, Samuel... Without breaking stride, Marion throws muskets to Nathan and Samuel who catch them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret, take William and Susan to the river shed.  Hide there.  If we're not back by dawn, go up the river to the Richardson's house. They'll take you to your Aunt Charlotte's farm.  Nathan, Samuel, and I are going to get Gabriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what about Thomas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave him.  Take care of William and Susan. Marion runs off toward the woods, Nathan and Samuel follow.  Margaret hesitates, then herds William and Susan toward the river.  The house is enveloped in flames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion runs, breathing hard, keeping a punishing, steady pace.  Nathan and Samuel run behind, less winded than their father.  Marion makes up with cold fury what he lacks in youth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion runs up to the crest of a wooded hill.  Slows. Crawls the last few feet.  Nathan and Samuel just behind him.  Looks over the hillside. A path runs through a glen, about fifty feet below. Marion's eyes dart, absorbing the terrain, looking for advantage.  He points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan, there.  Samuel, there. The boys go where they're told.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll fire first.  Then, Nathan, kill whoever is standing closest to Gabriel.  Samuel, kill the last man in the line. They stagger under the weight of the orders.  Marion notices but continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After that, Samuel, load for Nathan. If something happens to me, put down your weapons and run as fast as you can, that way, downhill.  Hide in the brush by the river, then make your way home, get the others and go to Aunt Charlotte's farm. The boys hesitate.  Marion looks at them firmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys... steady. NATHAN & SAMUEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, father. Marion disappears into the underbrush.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN THE PATH
dialogues.text: The dozen Redcoats approach.  Leading Gabriel on the rope

dialogues.speaker: AHEAD OF THEM
dialogues.text: Marion waits in the thick undergrowth. On the hillside, Nathan and Samuel grip their muskets and exchange a frightened, troubled look. The REDCOATS enter the glen. MARION waits, then picks his moment and FIRES, killing th Redcoat Lieutenant with a shot to the chest. NATHAN AND SAMUEL INSTANTLY FIRE, dropping the last Redcoat in the line and the one holding Gabriel's rope. THE REDCOATS STOP in confusion... GABRIEL kneels, out of the line of fire. The REDCOAT SERGEANT takes command...

dialogues.speaker: FORM BY TWOS
dialogues.text: MARION KILLS the Sergeant with a shot to the throat... Samuel finishes reloading, swaps muskets with Nathan who FIRES, DROPPING ANOTHER REDCOAT.

dialogues.speaker: READY...
dialogues.text: Marion FIRES, killing the Corporal, the last man of rank... Marion ducks to the side as a VOLLEY OF REDCOAT MUSKET FIRE tears into the spot marked by Marion's rifle smoke.. FROM THIS MOMENT ON, MARION NEVER STOPS MOVING.  He strides rather than runs, staying just inside the brush, offering only glimpses of himself.  He changes his pace and direction repeatedly, ducking and weaving, firing and loading while moving.  He never gives the Redcoats a stationary target, especially one marked by billowing smoke from his flintlock.  It's an Indian tactic and it works. The Redcoats TRACK HIM WITH THEIR BARRELS, about to fire... Marion suddenly STOPS DEAD, REVERSES DIRECTION, several REDCOATS FIRE AND MISS. Six Redcoats left.  Some primed, some reloading.  A REDCOAT draws a bead on Marion who drops to the ground an FIRES, killing him. Samuel, WEEPING as he loads, hands a primed musket to Nathan who FIRES... The Redcoats turn their attention to THE SPOT MARKED BY NATHAN'S SMOKE... Marion SEES THE REDCOATS AIMING TOWARD THE BOYS.  He instantly STRIDES OUT INTO THE OPEN, drawing the Redcoats attention from his sons... Marion FIRES BOTH HIS PISTOLS, killing two Redcoats... One Redcoat finishes reloading... Marion rushes him, shoves aside the barrel and SLAMS him in the face with th butt of the musket... This is a DIFFERENT MARION, a vicious, savage Marion, killing with stunning brutality... Marion drops his own expended rifle and CATCHES THE REDCOAT'S LOADED MUSKET before it hits the ground shoves that musket into another Redcoat's belly and FIRES... Two Redcoats left, neither finished loading... MARION CHARGES, drawing his TOMAHAWK, ignores a GLANCING BAYONET WOUND to the neck, HACKS a Redcoat open... Splattering himself with BLOOD... The final Redcoat, a cherubic-face young man, ducks into the woods... Marion tears after him... A FOOTRACE... the young Redcoat BLASTING THROUGH THE BRUSH... the older Marion, panting, losing ground... A CLEARING... the Redcoat is almost to the cover of the trees on the far side... MARION THROWS HIS TOMAHAWK which FLIES through the air an SINKS IN THE REDCOAT'S BACK... Marion runs to the wounded Redcoat, grabs his hair, yanks back his head and SLITS HIS THROAT... Then, without pausing, Marion wrenches the tomahawk from the Redcoat's body, and races back toward his sons...

dialogues.speaker: AT THE GLEN
dialogues.text: Nathan and a weeping Samuel, stunned at the carnage, stumble down the hillside toward Gabriel.  Marion runs up and motions for them to stop. Marion, checks the Redcoats, making sure they're all dead

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel, reload.  Nathan, untie Gabriel. They quickly do so as Marion picks up a loaded musket and scans the road and the underbrush.  In a moment they're ready.  Marion finds his own Pennsylvania rifle, then he and his sons disappear into the underbrush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house and barns smolder.  Thomas' body lies in the yard.  Nearby, the bodies of the Patriot wounded, now dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret waits in the shed with William and Susan.  They hear a SOUND.  APPROACHING FOOTSTEPS.  Margaret pulls her sister and brother to her and waits. The door opens.  It's Marion and Gabriel, Nathan and Samuel.  Margaret and the little ones throw themselves into Marion's arms. Margaret notices the blood on Marion.  She hesitates but her relief tightens her embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion, trailed by his children, walks past the soldiers' bodies and the remains of their house. He kneels down next to Thomas' body.  On the ground Mario sees several of THOMAS' LEAD SOLDIERS.  He stares at them for a moment, picks them up and puts them in his pocket. Marion picks up Thomas and carries him up the hill toward the apple tree and Elizabeth's grave.  The children follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion digs a grave.  The children watch.  The only sound are Marion's labored BREATHING, the RASP OF THE SHOVEL an the RUSTLE OF DEAD LEAVES blown along the ground by a sof wind. Some dry leaves catch on Thomas' still wet blood, as if trying to bandage his wound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion puts the last shovelfuls of dirt on the grave. Near tears and unsure of what to do next, he turns to Elizabeth's gravestone.  The soft wind blows.  Marion listens. He turns and sees his children looking up at him.  Holdin in his own tears, he gathers the children around him and let's them cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, there... he's alright... he's with your mother now... He stiffens, speaking formally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord, we pray that You accept this child, Thomas Marion and give him a place at Your side with his mother. We ask that You embrace him and help us to understand the manner in which Your mercy works.  This we ask, in Your name.  Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen. Marion looks at Elizabeth's grave, then he gently eases his children away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion and his children stop at the overlook, seeing the Santee River valley spread out before them.  The SMOKE from two dozen farms rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Morgans, the Halseys, Williams, Stantons... The smoke from the separate fires joins together high in the sky, forming what looks like stormclouds.  They walk on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion and his children wait in the cover of the woods. They see a pair of shadowed figures coming toward them from the house, Gabriel and Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, it's safe. Marion hustles the children out of the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte sits, holding a sleeping Susan.  The other children lie awake on pallets.  Marion, still streaked with dried blood and sweat, tucks William and Margaret into bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleep, now. Marion moves on to Nathan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father... I killed those men...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't blame yourself, you did what I told you to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad I killed them... I'm glad... Marion isn't.  He turns to Samuel who's cried-out.  Mario reaches out to touch him but Samuel recoils from Marion's blood-streaked hand.  Marion sighs and tucks him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try to get some sleep. Marion moves to take Susan from Charlotte who shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll stay with them. Marion nods and leaves Charlotte with the children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion enters.  He starts to pace but grows unsteady.  He rears back as if screaming but no sound comes from his mouth, as he looks upstairs, knowing his children are searching for the solace of sleep. He opens a cabinet, pulls out a bottle of liquor, pours and drinks.  Then another. THE SOUND OF HORSEMEN.  Gabriel walks in.  Tired.  Grim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are they? Marion just shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gates is at Hillsboro with the Continental Army.  I'll leave in the morning to join him. Marion nods.  Marion and Gabriel stand in silence for a long moment, neither one finding words.  Then Gabriel speaks softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tend my horse. He leaves Marion alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion stares at the fireplace.  Charlotte walks in carrying a pitcher and fresh clothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're asleep. Marion is silent.  Charlotte pours water into a washbowl and motions to Marion.  He takes off his shirt.  She begins cleaning away the blood and tending the wound on his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did this... how did I let this happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You couldn't have known.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should have known... once I would have... I used to be wary... and today I watched my son killed before my eyes... your sister civilized me and I damn myself for having let her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas is dead but you've done nothing for which you should be ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've done nothing and for that I am ashamed. She looks at him closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you go, I'll care for them as if they were my own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll leave in the morning with Gabriel. He stares past her, looking at the flames in the fireplace.  She tends his wounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion and Gabriel finish saddling their horses.  Marion embraces Nathan and Samuel.  Then he turns to Margaret, William and Susan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When will you be back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, William.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow? Marion winces.  Margaret puts her arm around William.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not tomorrow. Marion kisses them both, then moves on to Susan, trying t coax a word out of the silent four-year-old:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye? She just looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just one word?  Goodbye?  That's all I want. Susan shakes her head.  He sighs, rises and turns to Charlotte.  They hesitate, then embrace, hugging deeply but a bit awkwardly, holding each other just a moment longer than one would expect.  She looks up at him... he kisses her on the cheek. Marion mounts up.  And he and Gabriel head off, Susan, unnoticed and unheard, whispers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye. Marion and Gabriel ride away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion and Gabriel ride past the signs of a small skirmish.  Bodies.  Abandoned wagons.  Dead horses.  A burning farm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion and Gabriel ride to the crest of a hill.  A vista spreads out before them.  They see an awesome sight -- A MASSIVE SLASH OF RED approaches a MASSIVE SLASH OF BLUE. A battle is taking place about five miles away. Gabriel starts to spur his horse but Marion restrains him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's too late. Gabriel stops.  Marion points out brightly colored clusters of men behind each army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Command posts... Patriot... British... The distant slash of red stops.  Marion and Gabriel hear only a GENTLE WIND and some nearby SONGBIRDS. Then, from a black mass of the side of the red slash, a sudden, silent eruption of white smoke. An instant later, the blue slash quivers.  A moment later the SOUND OF THE CANNONS, RUMBLES UP THE HILL and rolls over Marion and Gabriel. The RED SLASH STOPS moving.  It darkens as thousands of Redcoats raise their muskets and the front ranks kneel into firing position. Marion's eyes dart.  He knows what's coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Break for the trees... break for the trees... A MASSIVE ERUPTION OF WHITE SMOKE billows from the red slash.  An instant later, the blue line starts to break u as hundreds of distant Patriots fall. The SOUND OF THE BRITISH MUSKETS reaches Marion and Gabriel like the pattering of rain. Then the SMOKE OF INEFFECTIVE, SCATTERED VOLLEYS erupts from the Patriot lines.  The red line holds firm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send them to cover!  Goddamn you! But the blue line of the Patriots stays in the open field From behind the Redcoats, FAST-MOVING GREEN AND RED MASSE move quickly onto the battlefield.  CAVALRY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, we have to do something... The British cavalry slams into the blue line, shattering it.  Tiny bits of blue move in every direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's already over. Marion watches, appalled.  At this distance the moving slashes of color and billowing smoke are strangely beautiful.  Marion turns his horse and heads down the hill, toward the rear of the Patriot lines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nightmare.  SCREAMS OF AGONY.  A few hundred battered, Patriot survivors treat their wounded and prepare to move out.  The battle, so bloodless and beautiful at a distance, has, in its aftermath, become horrifically painful and ugly. Marion and Gabriel ride into camp, passing nervous sentries and a field surgery which is surrounded by pools of blood and amputated legs and arms.  Marion sees HARRY LEE at a make-shift command post, barking orders, trying to pull things together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn you, Sergeant, don't move the wounded twice, put them straight on the wagons from the surgeons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant, detail men for outriders.  We move out as soon as the wounded are ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. The Lieutenant rushes off.  Lee notices Marion and Gabriel, surprised to see them.  He jerks his head for them to follow him into:

dialogues.speaker: LEE'S COMMAND TENT
dialogues.text: Once out of sight of the men, Lee loses his command bearing.  Exhausted, he leans on his campaign table and looks closely at Marion, asking with his eyes why Marion is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green Dragoons came to my home, killed my son, Thomas.  It was Tarleton himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I wasn't here for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing you could have done, Gates is a damned fool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We saw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I begged him to stay in the cover of the trees but he insisted the only way to break Cornwallis was muzzle- to-muzzle.  He spent too many years in the British army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last anyone saw, riding hard, northeast, his staff a hundred yards behind, trying to catch up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's in command?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am, I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are my orders? Lee gives Marion a tired smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want orders, I've got some for you. Lee ROLLS OUT A MAP for Marion and Gabriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're a breath away from losing this war.  In the North, Washington is reeling from Valley Forge, running and hiding from Clinton and twelve thousand Redcoats. (pointing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here in the South, Cornwallis has broken our back.  He captured over five thousand of our troops when he took Charleston and today he destroyed the only army that stood between him and New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So now Cornwallis will head north, link up with Clinton and finish off Washington.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Patriots will start dying on the gallows instead of the battlefield. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless we can keep Cornwallis in the South until the French arrive.  A treaty was signed at Versailles after our victory at Saratoga.  The French are sending a fleet and ten thousand troops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fall, six months at the earliest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bigger problem is where, not when.  The French fleet won't sail north of the Chesapeake for fear of early storms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're going to try to keep Cornwallis in the South until then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not me, you.  I'm going north with every Continental regular I can find to reinforce Washington or he won't last six weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You expect Cornwallis to be held here by militia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not held, just slowed down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're nothing but farmers and you're asking them to try to keep a tiger in their backyard.  They'd be better off letting it move on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'd be better off, but the cause wouldn't be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many men does Cornwallis have under his command?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four thousand infantry and around six hundred cavalry... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... including the Green Dragoons under Tarleton. At the mention of Tarleton, Marion nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do what I can. Lee quickly writes something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm giving you a field commission as a colonel. He hands it to Marion.  Gabriel steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Lee, I request a transfer to Colonel Marion's command.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Granted. Lee scribbles another order and hands it to Gabriel.  The he turns to Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck. Marion nods.  They duck out of the tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion and Gabriel stand watching Lee and his Continental regulars move out.  Gabriel turns to Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What now, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We put out the word.  We'll start along the south side of the Santee...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd cover more ground if we split up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's safer if we stay together. Gabriel steps in front of Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel, I didn't request this transfer because you're my father. I requested it because I believe in this cause and this is where I can do the most good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been doing this for two years. I'm the best scout in the Continental Army, the best horseman, the best shot, the best scavenger and I know every deer path and swamp trail between here and Charleston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father taught me. Marion looks at Gabriel closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did your father teach you humility?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tried.  It didn't take. Marion looks Gabriel up and down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, Corporal, you take Bennington, Harrisville, Acworth and the farms along Black Swamp.  I'll take the north side of the river. We'll meet at Snow's Island.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. They mount up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, Corporal... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... be careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... father. They ride off in different directions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion rides into a small village, passing several bodies in blue Continental uniforms, hanging from lampposts. Marion stops in front of a tavern, dismounts and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Marion walks in he's greeted by cold stares from half- a-dozen men, huddles over their drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for John Billings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dead. Marion looks closely at the grim, suspicious men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he comes back from the dead, tell him Francis Marion is looking for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be sure to do that. As Marion turns to leave he notices an open bottle of Madeira on one of the tables.  He stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll wait.  Miracles happen. A stand-off.  Then, a hulking FIGURE appears in the shadows at the back doorway.  He's JOHN BILLINGS, big, coarse, about Marion's age.  Billings jerks his head for Marion to join him in the back room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark.  Marion and billings talk over a bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You expect to hold Cornwallis with militia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I expect to try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust you and Harry Lee.  Remember that damned overland you two thought up in '62 to hit Fort Louis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It worked.  How many men can you raise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not many.  Dalton, Scott, they've got their reasons; Rev. Oliver, he believes in the cause; some of the young bucks; a few like me with nothing to lose... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
