dialogues.text: What about you?  You've got a lot to lose. Marion drains his glass and stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You coming, or not? Billings drains his glass.  They walk out together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion and Billings ride away from the tavern, passing th hanging Patriot bodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CACOPHONY OF BIRDS AND INSECTS.  Swamp maples and willows form a canopy over moss-covered mounds and pools of plant-choked water. Gabriel leads several men, riding along a dry path that snakes through the swamp.  They cross a narrow land bridg onto a wooded island, joining a dozen-and-a-half men, including Marion who kneels at a campfire. CLOSE SHOT:  Several of Thomas' brightly painted LEAD SOLDIERS MELT in a cast-iron pan.  The little men fall to their knees then lose form, turning into bubbling, molten metal. The new arrivals dismount and greet the others. Gabriel steps up behind Marion and watches as he pours th lead into a bullet mold, closes the lid and dips the mold into a bucket of water which HISSES and STEAMS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, this war is about more than Thomas. Marion doesn't look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're here only for revenge, you're doing a disservice to him as well as yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how old I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God help us all when you're forty. Marion puts some more lead soldiers into the pan.  Gabrie shakes his head, turns away and goes to tend his horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Day breaks.  A low, thick swamp mist covers the encampment.  Marion, sits alone by the embers of last night's campfire.  The men are awake.  Some eat, others talk. Marion pulls himself out of his dark reverie.  He takes the bullets from the mold and puts them in a pouch attached to his weapons' belt.  Then he rises and heads over to the men. He surveys his brigade.  Twenty-six men:  framers, artisans, mountain men, none in uniform.  Marion walks among them, nodding familiarly to several.  He notices an imposing looking Cherokee Indian, BROTHER JOSEPH, standin a bit apart from the others.  They exchange nods. He notices a stern-looking man in partial clerical garb, REV. CHARLES OLIVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard about your son.  I'm sorry. Marion accepts his condolences.  He notes GEORGE DALTON, tough-looking, rustic man with an ice-cold, distant stare

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dalton. Dalton doesn't respond.  Marion recognizes another face, ABNER BROWN, African-American, around thirty, rugged. Marion addresses the men who do not gather around so much as just give him their attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all have your own reasons for being here.  I lost a son and I intend to kill the man who killed him... Marion pauses and looks over at Gabriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... But I don't consider that man's life adequate payment for the life of my son, and killing him won't keep the sons of other men from dying... Gabriel nods, approvingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cornwallis has to move north.  We have to keep him right here.  If he's south of the Chesapeake when the French arrive, if the French arrive, we have a chance of winning this war. Marion looks from face to face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eat, get some rest, we move out in two hours. Marion heads back to his campsite, passing Gabriel withou looking at him, but very aware of his son's eyes on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A massive British army field encampment.  Thousands of well-armed, veteran troops.  Large detachments of Redcoat march through endless rows of tents.  Some are battle- worn, others are fresh troops moving out. TARLETON and his GREEN DRAGOONS, covered with dirt and sweat, ride into the encampment.  Tarleton and Wilkins peel off, riding to the front of a farmhouse that has bee commandeered for British headquarters.  They dismount and stride in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: British officers, clerks and aides work.  They're in good spirits.  LORD CORNWALLIS, a proud man, comfortable with command, coldly notes one of his officers slapping anothe on the back.  MAJOR HUNTINGTON rolls out a map for Cornwallis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen. The officers gather around the map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major, this is not an adequate map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have better coming on the trailing supply convoy from Charleston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A useful place for our maps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir, it won't happen again. Tarleton enters, followed by Wilkins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My harrier.  Join us, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir. Tarleton and Wilkins join them around the map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, celebration is premature. We have a difficult campaign ahead of us.  We are in predominately hostile country and we cannot rely on forage.  As we move north, the bulk of our supplies will reach us by sea, through Charleston, which will give us a long and vulnerable supply line, one that can only be secured if the locals are loyal to the crown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (multiple)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Cornwallis turns to his field officers, paying particular attention to Tarleton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonetheless, we must remember that this is a civil war... Tarleton proudly holds Cornwallis' look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These colonials are our brethren and when this conflict is over, we will be reestablishing commerce with them.  Surrendering troops will be given quarter and unwarranted assaults on civilians will cease. Wilkins shifts uneasily.  Tarleton isn't cowed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I expect this war to be fought in a vigorous but civilized manner. Cornwallis looks at his other officers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have I made myself clear, gentlemen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (multiple)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Cornwallis shifts his eyes back to Tarleton who was not among those who spoke.  Tarleton pointedly pauses a moment, then says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Cornwallis turns his attention back to the map.  His men gather around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tarleton and Wilkins walk out and mount up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe he was speaking to us, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know that Lord Cornwallis' father was a tenant on the estate of my grandfather? Tarleton jerks his reins and rides off.  Wilkins laughs and follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A British supply train of several dozen wagons, a herd of horses and accompanying Redcoats makes its way. ON A WOODED HILLSIDE, Gabriel lies on the ground, observing the convoy.  He eases back, mounts up, and ride off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion and his men wait, well-hidden in the brush on a rise, just above the bridge.  Gabriel rides up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Less than a mile.  Forty-one wagons, a company of Redcoat infantry, horses at the rear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flanking riders?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't see any. Marion nods and motions to his men who check their weapon and pass the word.  Gabriel ties up his horse and takes a position near his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The British convoy rounds the curve.  When two-thirds of the wagons have crossed the bridge, Marion FIRES, killing the Redcoat of highest rank, a CAPTAIN. BILLINGS AND DALTON heave CORKED BOTTLES which break, spreading their OILY CONTENTS on the wooden bridge. BROTHER JOSEPH fires a FLAMING ARROW, igniting the oil. The BRIDGE BURSTS INTO FLAMES, cutting off the tail of th convoy, stranding a dozen wagons and the herd of horses o Marion's side of the river. A REDCOAT LIEUTENANT takes command.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the river!  Covering fire! Double rank! Marion calls to his men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Epaulets first... Kill the officers. Marion and his men FIRE A WITHERING VOLLEY, KILLING ALL REDCOATS OF RANK -- two lieutenants, a sergeant and several corporals. The LEADERLESS REDCOAT PRIVATES take cover as Marion's me OPEN UP on the Redcoats on their side of the river.

dialogues.speaker: THE WAGONS
dialogues.text: With half of his men FIRING COVER, Marion and the other half run to the wagons, passing Redcoat dead and wounded... DALTON, notices a WOUNDED REDCOAT and pauses... The Redcoat looks up imploringly at Dalton who finishes reloading, then coldly FIRES, KILLING THE helpless Redcoat... Marion, Gabriel and Rev. Oliver see Dalton kill the wounded Redcoat as they race toward the wagons, British musketballs SPLINTERING TREES all around them... The horses nearest the burning bridge are terrified, BUCKING AND REARING, STRUGGLING in their traces... MARION LEAPS INTO THE SEAT of one wagon.  Gabriel and Billings grab the reins of two more wagons. The Redcoats keep up a STEADY FIRE.  TWO OF MARION'S MEN FALL, one dead another wounded. Marion, Gabriel and Billings STRUGGLE TO CONTROL THE FRIGHTENED HORSES, backing them up around the curve to th cover of the woods. MARION'S REARGUARD, Brother Joseph, Abner, Dan Scott and others, withdraws in leapfrog, FIRING BACK ACROSS THE RIVER. BRITISH MUSKET BALLS SLAM into the trees and SPLINTER THE WAGONS... Another of Marion's men is WOUNDED.  Two of his comrades HEAVE HIM onto one of the wagons... As Marion's men get the wagons turned and unblocked from each other, they DRIVE THEM OFF, one after another... Brother Joseph, Abner and the rest of the rearguard make it to Marion and LEAP INTO HIS WAGON... MARION snaps the reins and they THUNDER OFF, away from th BURNING BRIDGE and the FIRING Redcoats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion's men tend their wounded and look through the British wagons, taking inventory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... two-hundred-sixty-six Brown Bess muskets, forty-one casks of powder, balls, tamping...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have enough arms for an army. Now all we need is an army. Marion checks out a wagon full of tools with DAN SCOTT an ROB FIELDING, a couple of sharp-eyed craftsmen.  They overlap dialogue, rapidly speaking the private language o colonial artisans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reamer, boring tool...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swage, broach, etching tool...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rolling gunsmith's shop...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can rifle those musket barrels...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get another hundred yards out of 'em...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll need a forge...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy enough...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got clay to make a chamber...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oak to make charcoal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oil cloth and barrel staves to make a bellows...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we can yank a wagon wheel, weight it, rig a piston and drive shaft and we'll have a flywheel to power the bellows... Scott and Fielding exchange an impressed look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Fielding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why he's a colonel. Scott and Fielding roll up their sleeves and get to work. Marion hears a COMMOTION OF BARKING DOGS AND YELLING MEN and strides over to find Billings cowering before TWO HUG GREAT DANES who stand guard at one of the wagons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot them!  Shoot the damn things! Dalton prepares to do so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put that pistol down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They followed us from the bridge. They won't let anyone near the wagon. Marion steps forward, speaking softly but firmly to the dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay... stay... stay... The dogs waver between obeying Marion and ripping out his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you growl at me! The dogs decide to obey.  Marion lets them sniff his hand then firmly pats them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let's see what's in this wagon. Rev. Oliver and Abner join him.  Billings eases past the dogs.  Abner opens a large case and finds it filled with bottles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rum, French Champagne, Madeira, Port...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No wonder they were guarding it. Gabriel opens a trunk and finds it filled with powdered wigs, all perfectly coifed and stored on head-shaped wig- stands.  Rev. Oliver opens one of several identical cases and finds it filled with papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My heavens, personal correspondence of... Lord Cornwallis. Marion grabs some papers, scans them, then finds matching cases on nearby wagons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These four wagons must be his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the dogs, too, I'll wager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say we drink the wine, shoot the dogs, and use the papers for musket wadding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His journals, letters, maps, books... Abner calls from another wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel, we got a wagon full of officer's uniforms and more powder and muskets here. Ignoring Abner, Marion, sits down on a stump with a pile of Cornwallis' papers and starts to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion sits at Cornwallis' ornate, folding campaign desk, reading Cornwallis' journal, surrounded by Cornwallis' field gear which includes furniture, music boxes, oil paintings and an elaborate folding commode.  The TWO GREA DANES sit nearby, eyeing Marion warily. The men have divided themselves into two groups, one coarse, the other civilized, each clustered around a separate fire. The coarse men, including Dalton, Brother Joseph and RANDOLPH, a grizzled, black-toothed mountain man, drink and laugh loudly, wearing Cornwallis' wigs askew. The civilized men, including Rev. Oliver, Gabriel, Scott, Fielding and Abner, talk quietly. Marion puts down the journal and walks over to the campfire where the rougher men are gathered.  He stands just inside the firelight and speaks loudly, so that all can hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today was hard earned but a good start. Marion looks at Dalton, then turns to the other men as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the future wounded British soldiers will be given quarters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like they gave quarter to my family? My wife and three children were hiding in our root cellar when they came.  The Redcoats locked the door and torched the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have my sympathy... but the order stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who are you to give an order like that?  We all know what you did after Fort Wilderness. That hits home but Marion remains calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm your commanding officer.  This is militia, not regular army.  I can't hold you here, but as long as you stay, you'll follow my orders. Marion looks from face to face.  Most begrudgingly nod. That's enough for Marion. As he heads back to his own campfire he's intercepted by Rev. Oliver who speaks to him out of earshot of the other men, except for Gabriel and Billings who overhear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For trying to impose some decency on that sort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't depend on my decency.  I'm one of that sort. Marion walks on.  Rev. Oliver exchanges a look with Gabriel, then heads off.  As Marion joins Gabriel and Billings at his campfire, Billings grips his bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I one of that sort?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the worst of that sort. You're the sort that gives that sort a bad name. Billings considers that, then shrugs and takes a long drink.  He hands the bottle to Marion who takes an equall long drink.  Marion picks up his Pennsylvania rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to check the watch. He disappears into the darkness leaving Gabriel and Billings at the campfire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shouldn't make light.  That Redcoat should not have been killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not making light. Gabriel shoots Billings a dubious look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know him very well, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's my father. Billings looks closely at Gabriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know him well enough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't fault him for having grown up on the frontier.  It was a harder time and a harder place than you know. Gabriel looks at Billings, then turns back to the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are beginning to stir, gathering around the campfires, cooking, using pots, pans and other gear from the stolen British wagons. Marion reads Cornwallis' journal.  He looks up, stretches and walks over to a campfire where Gabriel, Billings and Rev. Oliver cook.  The dogs follow at a distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've just been inside the mind of a genius.  Lord Cornwallis knows more about war than I could in a dozen lifetimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheerful news to greet the morn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His victories at Charleston and Camden were perfect, strategically, tactically, logistically.  But he has a weakness. They all turn to Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord Cornwallis is brilliant.  His weakness is that he knows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pride is his weakness. The men consider that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Personally, I'd prefer stupidity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pride will do. BEGIN MONTAGE:  Series of shots as follows: -- A VOLLEY OF MUSKET FIRE erupts from some thick underbrush, cutting down half of a squadron of Redcoats on the march.  The surviving Redcoats FIRE BACK into the trees at unseen targets to little effect. -- Marion rides with about fifty men. -- A British supply convoy makes its way through the woods.  Suddenly, Marion's men appear, rising up from the ground as if by magic, having been camouflaged by leaves and brush.  They OPEN FIRE on the convoy escort, which holds for a moment, then flees. -- Marion rides with about seventy-five men. -- Cornwallis finishes reading a dispatch and furiously flings it across the room. -- Marion rides with about one hundred men. -- Snow's Island.  Marion and his men do an inventory of large haul of stolen British supply wagons.  The booty includes dozens of BRASS MUSICAL INSTRUMENTS, some of which Marion's men BLARE in celebration. -- Marion rides with about one-hundred-fifty men. -- Marion, Gabriel, and some of the other men watch as th flaming supports of a BURNING WOODEN BRIDGE collapse into a river. -- A seething Cornwallis stands at the same spot, looking at the charred, now cooled, remains of the bridge. Cornwallis angrily mounts up and rides off.  His contrite staff officers mount up and follow. -- Snow's Island.  Marion sits with his muddy feet on Cornwallis' campaign desk, reading Cornwallis' journal, with Cornwallis' Great Danes at his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glittering lights shine from the Camden Inn, a grand structure in the center of town. A line of OPULENT CARRIAGES discharges well-dressed passengers, arriving for a ball.  Ladies in their finery. Patrician husbands.  Redcoat and Green Dragoon officers i magnificent dress uniforms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cornwallis, standing in front of a full-length mirror, is dressed by his VALET while Major Halbert, Colonel Huntington and Tarleton look on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why am I here, Colonel Halbert?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the ball, sir? Cornwallis holds his temper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, after six weeks, are we still here to attend a ball.  By now, we should be attending balls in North Carolina, not South Carolina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our supply line, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent guess, Major. The valet puts a dress coat on Cornwallis who looks at th garment with deepest disdain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what, praytell, is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... I borrowed it from Colonel North.  I took it in at the back, added wider epaulets, a court sash and looped gold braiding on the cuffs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a horse blanket. (to Major Halbert)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First my personal baggage, then half the bridges and ferries between here and Charleston burned, a dozen convoys attacked.  Colonel, if you can't secure our supply line against militia, how do you expect to do so against Colonial regulars or the French when they come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, they're not like regulars, we can't find them and we don't know when or where they're going to strike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How impolite.  And who leads these clever, secretive fellows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't know, sir.  He's called, the Commander by some, the Swamp Fox by others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel, I'm a civilized man but I'm finding to difficult to remain civil.  Secure my supply line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Cornwallis looks at his reflection with dismay, sighs and strides out.  Tarleton, amused, follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the far end of town Marion, Gabriel, Billings, Dalton, Scott and several other men slip through the shadows into an alley.  The lights from the ball shine from down the street and the MUSICAL STRAINS of a MINUET drift to them through the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A block-like building on the far edge of town.  A pair of REDCOATS stand guard.  A PAIR OF DRUNKEN REDCOATS stagger out of a side-street, SINGING A MUMBLING SONG.  The Redcoat guards look at the drunk Redcoats enviously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what you got there? The drunken Redcoats look up, bringing their faces into the light -- THE DRUNKEN REDCOATS ARE BILLINGS AND DALTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got our own little party...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To hell with the officers and their fancy dress ball...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give us a nip, here. Billings and Dalton walk over to the Redcoats guards.  As the guards reach for the bottles, Billings SLAMS one of the guards back against the building... Dalton DRAWS A KNIFE and PLUNGES IT into the second guard's belly and HACKS HIM OPEN... Dalton shoves Billings out of the way, SLITS THE OTHER GUARD'S THROAT.  Billings is taken aback by the speed and ferocity of Dalton's attack... Marion and Scott duck into the shadows of the doorway, pull out hammer-less carving chisels and quickly and silently start gouging out the wood around the hinges of the heavy door. Billings and Dalton take the posts of the guards while th other men drag the bodies of the real guards out of sight Everything appears as it should.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grand.  Opulent.  Cornwallis speaks with a small gatherin of loyalist civilians, among whom is the spectacular MRS. TALBOT, who wears a daring dress that reveals an enormous expanse of bosom.  At her side stands her toady of a husband, MR. TALBOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  The beasts took your dogs, as well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine animals, a gift from His Majesty.  Dead now, for all I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there no decency?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Among the rebels?  We know the answer to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, we have learned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion and Scott shove their chisels through the door which falls away from the hinges.  They all duck inside finding barrels and casks of gunpowder, boxes of weapons and hundreds of muskets. Gabriel and the others load themselves up with the best o the weapons as Marion opens a cask and pours a trail of gunpowder across the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cornwallis, taking the night air with Mrs. Talbot, gazes at the moon, achieving the calculated effect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem far away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the weight of command and the lot of a widower -- memories, loneliness... (with a self- deprecating laugh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and long gazes at the moon. Mrs. Talbot sympathetically sighs and touches her fingertips to her heart which is conveniently located inches above her stunning cleavage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you poor man... A MASSIVE EXPLOSION LIGHTS UP THE NIGHT as a FIREBALL erupts from the armory.  British officers, including Majo Halbert and Tarleton, RUSH OUT along with Mr. Talbot and other Loyalist civilians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good God! Mr. Talbot tears his eyes from the flames and looks at his wife, clinging to Cornwallis' arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These rebels seem to lack fear as well as decency, eh, General? Cornwallis registers the insult, glances at the hapless Major Halbert, then turns to Tarleton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Tarleton, you deal with these damned rebels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Tarleton smiles grimly and strides off the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The village of Pembroke lies nestled in a valley, surrounded by tilled fields and small farms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty of Marion's men water their horses.  Marion, with the two Great Danes at his side, speaks with PETER GREEN, a middle-aged storekeeper with a marked limp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... four baskets of apples, salt pork, sweet potatoes, jerky, hard tack, salt and powder.  It's not much, but I'll get you more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't pay for this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you what I can, when I can.  You pay me what you can. Green's daughter, ANNE, very attractive, around sixteen, joins them.  Gabriel sees her and sidles over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francis, you remember my daughter, Anne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to see you again, Anne. Gabriel clears his throat.  Anne looks at him coolly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know who you are, Gabriel Marion. The last time I saw you, I was nine and you put ink in my tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... uh... that wasn't me, it was Samuel... I mean Nathan...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was you and it turned my teeth black for a month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's sorry.  Come. Green heads across the square where some townspeople are giving Marion's men provisions.  Anne and Gabriel follow. Marion turns to some waiting men, new recruits. Billings, nearby, reads A POSTED BROADSHEET that announces:  "Reward Offered:  For the capture or death of the rebel known as 'The Swamp Fox'". He tears it down and walks over to Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and your terms of enlistment will be month-to-month.  Every thirty days you can re-enlist or return to your families. REED, the sturdiest of the lot offers his hand to Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in. The others nod in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk to Abner and Scott about provisions, powder and mounts. The recruits head off.  Billings hands Marion the wanted poster which Marion glances at and crumbles up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty men here, seventeen in New Brighton, a dozen along the Black River.  We'll pass three hundred by week's end if this keeps up.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE SQUARE
dialogues.text: Gabriel and several of Marion's men take supplies from Green, Anne, and some other townspeople.  Gabriel looks a Anne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I'd known you were going to look like this, I never would have put ink in your tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You call that a compliment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a start. She gives him a bit of a smile.  He checks out her teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look nice.  As white as can be. She tries to glare but she can't help but laugh. MARION AND BILLINGS watch as Anne gives Gabriel some apples which he tosses into the air, one-by-one, catching them behind his back, a cocky move, executed with a disarming smile that makes Anne laugh again.  Marion smiles at his son's flirtation.  Billings smiles as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reminds me of you before you got old and ugly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he takes after his mother... Billings is taken aback by the gentleness of Marion's words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... the younger ones barely remember her but Gabriel spent more time with Elizabeth... she taught him well, guided him, she was his North Star and mine... her father was a minister, in Boston, did you know that? Billings nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Gabriel's already a better man than I could ever hope to be... Marion hears himself and pulls his eyes from Gabriel, adopting a coarse, joking tone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, old and ugly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got me beat on both accounts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hell I do. They mount up, grateful to leave the sincerity behind. Gabriel sees Marion and his men starting to ride off.  He says goodbye to Anne, then RUNS TO HIS HORSE, MOUNTING WITH A DRAMATIC LEAP.  He GALLOPS up, taking his place at his father's side.  Marion doesn't turn to look at him, but he knows he's there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A patchwork of fields with a village visible in the distance.  The ROLLINS BOYS, 10 and 12, work a field, harvesting grain.  Hearing the SOUND OF HORSES' HOOVES, they stop and listen. Then they see a CLOUD OF DUST rising over the ridge line. Growing excited, they throw down their scythes and race down the hillside, madly stumbling and falling, trying to intersect the approaching sound. At the bottom of the hill they pass their father, BEN ROLLINS, who watches his sons plant themselves on the sid of the road, gazing in awe at: MARION AND HIS MEN, THUNDERING BY.  They're an impressive sight, a hundred-and-fifty heavily armed men, on powerful mounts, raising a cloud of dust as they gallop down the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion and forty of his men, including Gabriel, sit on their motionless horses in the middle of the road.  There are a number of new faces among Marion's men, among them Ben Rollins.  Gabriel is lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel?  Are you asleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're low on salt.  I should go to Pembroke and get some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got salt last week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, right. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baking powder, we need baking powder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got plenty of baking powder. You went to Pembroke and got five pounds two weeks ago. Gabriel sighs.  They hear a SOUND APPROACHING, then see two British wagons round a curve with a guard of only SIX REDCOATS, commanded by a REDCOAT SERGEANT.  The Redcoat Sergeant signals stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halt.  Look alive, boys. The young Redcoat privates nervously UNSHOULDER THEIR MUSKETS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant, this road is closed. Those wagons now belong to the Continental Army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready arms!  By twos! Marion's surprised by the Sergeant's order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant, there's no reason for you and your men to die.  Just leave the wagons and go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steady, boys... Marion sighs and lets loose with a PIERCING WHISTLE.  The underbrush parts and more of Marion's men show themselves MUSKETS LEVELED at the outnumbered Redcoats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the King's highway and I advise you and your men to make way. (to his men)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prepare to fire. Marion exchanges a look with Rev. Oliver who, like Marion doesn't want to kill these men.  Seeing no other option, Marion turns to give the order, then stops, hearing a FAINT BARELY DETECTABLE, RUMBLING SOUND... A moment later Brother Joseph hears it as well... HORSES HOOVES, LOTS OF THEM, growing louder by the second, THUNDERING toward them from the road behind the British wagons... Then, the SOUND OF MORE HORSES, coming in fast on both flanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a trap... The canvas sides of the British wagons are THROWN UP and DOZENS OF REDCOATS, armed with muskets, spill out... Marion's unmounted men run to their horses, LEAPING into their saddles... Then GREEN DRAGOONS appear, galloping down the wooded slopes on both flanks, astonishing horsemen, weaving through the trees without slacking their pace, SWORDS DRAWN, PISTOLS PRIMED...

dialogues.speaker: FIRE
dialogues.text: A THUNDEROUS VOLLEY ERUPTS from the Redcoat infantry, KILLING several of Marion's men... Marion's men FIRE BACK from their BUCKING MOUNTS, most of their shots going awry... Behind the British wagons, a huge detachment of GREEN DRAGOONS appears, TARLETON among them... MARION SEES THE DRAGOONS BUT NOT TARLETON HIMSELF... MARION AND HIS MEN spur their mounts, taking off down the road in the opposite direction... The FLANKING BODIES OF DRAGOONS gallop out of the woods, JOINING THE MAIN BODY, riding in hard pursuit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion and his men GALLOP down the road.  The much larger body of Green Dragoons THUNDER after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion and his men ride along a raised road that drops of into Black Swamp on either side... They ROUND A CURVE AND STOP, reining back their horses in confusion as they see: FIFTY GREEN DRAGOONS heading straight toward them... THE DRAGOONS OPEN FIRE from both directions, KILLING several more of Marion's men, WOUNDING others... Marion's men FIRE BACK as best they can, caught in the CHAOS OF BUCKING AND FALLING HORSES and WOUNDED AND DISMOUNTED MEN... They remount, doubling-up with the wounded... MARION sees an unaided wounded man.  LEAPS FROM HIS HORSE, heaves him onto his horse, slaps it... Marion's men head off both sides of the road into the swamp, struggling with their mounts as they hit the knee- deep water... Marion on foot with four men, only three horses... A DRAGOON, aiming his pistol, THUNDERS down on Marion... MARION FIRES, killing the Dragoon... Marion's men mount, one motions to Marion...

dialogues.speaker: GO
dialogues.text: Marion's men ride off, leaving him ALONE... a Dragoon is almost on him, SWORD RAISED.  Marion, his weapon spent, sees a thick branch on the ground, two feet long... grabs it... The sword flashes and SINKS DEEPLY INTO THE WOOD... Mario YANKS, brings the rider off his horse, grabs the reins an SWINGS HIMSELF UP INTO THE EMPTY SADDLE.  Marion rides down the embankment... The Dragoons rein back, slowed by the dead horses and men They spur their reluctant mounts over the bodies and follow Marion and his men into the swamp...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARION RIDES HARD, galloping along a circuitous, barely visible dry trail... A MOMENT LATER, Tarleton and Green Dragoons follow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARION CATCHES UP to a dozen of his men, including Gabrie and Billings.  Several of the men are badly wounded, barely clinging to their saddles... They ride through the shallow water, get to a fork, SPLIT UP.  As they disappear into the swamp, the sounds of thei horses are swallowed up in the LOUD BUZZING OF SWAMP INSECTS and the CRIES OF THE SWAMP BIRDS... A moment later, Tarleton and the vanguard of Dragoons rid up.  Tarleton signals stop at the fork... Looks... nothing.  Listens... nothing.  Chooses a path, the one Marion took.  Rides off, the Dragoons following..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darker still.  Tarleton and his men come to a dead end, blocked by a heavy tangle of huge swamp ferns and thorn bushes. They rein back their horses, stopping in a confused mess. Tarleton calls to Gaskins and the Loyalist scouts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way... no this... I think... Tarleton makes his own choice... rides off... the Green Dragoons follow, the Loyalists bring up the rear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tarleton and his mounted Dragoons struggle through a nearly impassable morass of swamp-grass, reeds and swarming mosquitoes... The exhausted Dragoons are wet, covered with mud, and bleeding from swamp briars.  The horses are spent and foaming... Tarleton struggles harder than any, but finally even he has had enough.  He reins back his horse.

dialogues.speaker: HALT
dialogues.text: Tarleton glares into the impenetrable darkness of plant- choked water and swamp...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough of this.  There are other ways to run down a fox. Tarleton yanks on his reins, turns his horse and starts back the way they came.  His grateful men turn their horses and follow. IN THE UNDERGROWTH, Marion, Gabriel, Billings and three badly wounded men, with only four horses between them, calm their mounts... They can hear, but not see the Dragoons.  Then, through the thick undergrowth, MARION CATCHES A GLIMPSE OF TARLETON... Gabriel, tending the wounded men, sees his father lock hi eyes on Tarleton... Marion quickly opens his weapons pouch and pulls out one of the bullets he made from Thomas' lead soldiers. Walking to his horse, Marion loads... Marion mounts, scanning the terrain, planning a route...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, no... As Marion spurs his horse to ride after Tarleton, Gabriel grabs the bridle.  He YANKS HARD, stopping Marion's horse dead.  THE HORSE BUCKS, nearly throwing Marion...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's him.  Tarleton. MARION SPURS THE HORSE which tries to respond but is JERKED BACK AGAIN by Gabriel.  Marion angrily turns on hi son...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn you!  Let go! Gabriel looks up at his father, never loosening his iron grip on the bridles but speaking softly, almost pleadingly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, please... Marion looks down at Gabriel.  Then Marion looks over at Billings and the three wounded men... One bleeds from an ugly neck wound... their shared mounts are nearly spent... Marion takes a last look in the direction of the departin Tarleton.  Then he dismounts and hurries over to help the wounded.  Gabriel watches his father for a moment, then joins him with the wounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark.  Marion and his battered men gather, taking stock. Men drift in, mounted and on foot in ones and twos, past wary sentries.  GABRIEL RIDES UP, dismounts and reports t Marion, out of earshot of the other men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fourteen dead, eleven wounded, eighteen captured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should have killed him when I had the chance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When was that?  In the swamp at the expense of your men?  Or when he killed Thomas at the expense of your family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or perhaps tomorrow at the expense of our cause. Marion is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There will be a time and a place for revenge but killing Tarleton at the expense of your duty serves no one but yourself. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay the course. The parental-sounding formality of Gabriel's words brings a thin smile to Marion's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay the course... your mother used to say that to me when I'd get drunk or lose my temper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'd say it to me when I picked on Thomas or Nathan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You learned her lessons better than I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She got me at a more impressionable age. Marion smiles, nods a silent thanks to his son and heads over to help with the wounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cold, winter rain falls.  Most of Marion's grim men are huddled in lean-to's and around campfires.  Green and several other Pembroke townspeople unload a wagon of supplies while Marion, Scott and Fielding stow the provisions. Gabriel and Anne sit at a fire, under the cover of a lean to, taking quietly.  He's troubled.  She tries to be hopeful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time we'll bring more blankets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we'll be lucky this winter and have just rain, no snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be nice, too. She takes a pot off the campfire and pours him a cup of tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just because the French didn't come this fall, doesn't mean they're never going to come. He nods and takes a drink of the tea.  She smiles. Gabriel smiles back to her, revealing a mouthful of ink- stained, black teeth.  Before she has time to laugh... ROLLINS RIDES HARD INTO CAMP.  Marion hurries over, accompanied by the Great Danes.  The other men gather around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're to be hung!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they're prisoners-of-war! Marion isn't as surprised as Gabriel.  He is, however, taken aback by Gabriel's black teeth.  Gabriel notices everyone looking at his mouth. Anne is embarrassed and regretful, seeing her joke fly in the face of the troubling news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A REDCOAT SENTRY sees a lone figure on horseback ride out of distant woods.  It's Rev. Oliver, carrying a white fla with one hand, holding a dispatch case in the other.  The sentry calls to the Commander of the Watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A temporary HQ has been set up in a commandeered farmhouse.  Cornwallis stands uncomfortably while a tailo measures him and marks alterations on a partially completed uniform.  Tarleton enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General, a message from the commander of the rebel militia. Cornwallis reads the message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems our Swamp Fox wants to have a formal parley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to meet with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most certainly.  Arrange it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion rides, trailed by Cornwallis' Great Danes.  Behind him, two dozen heavily armed Patriots, including Rev. Oliver who carries a white flag. A detachment of Redcoat Cavalry, lead by Major Halbert, waits.  The Redcoats fall in on either side.  They ride on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Redcoat sentries see the approaching Patriots and Redcoat and open the gates.  Billings and the other Patriots stop a hundred yards outside the barricades. MARION alone rides through the gates, flanked by the British cavalry, the Great Danes following closely behind

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major Halbert ushers Marion in.  The Great Danes follow sniffing curiously, sensing something or someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord Cornwallis will be with you presently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may, of course, keep your weapons, but I must warn you that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm familiar with appropriate behavior at a military parley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, quite, but you should know that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That will be all, Major.  I'll wait for Lord Cornwallis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... you will wait. Major Halbert turns and starts to stride out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One other thing. Major Halbert stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The proper form of address to a superior officer, even one of an opposing army, is "Yes, sir." Major Halbert sneers and strides from the room.  MARION ALONE, EXCEPT FOR THE DOGS, allows himself a fleeting smile.  Then he looks around the room.  He notes a rockin chair.  Curious, he hefts it.  Too heavy.  He puts it down, sits and rocks.  The dogs walk over and lay at his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion patiently sits rocking.  One of the dogs has its head in his lap and Marion scratches it behind the ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stone-faced Marion stands in the center of the room, playing with the dogs.  One of the dogs jumps up, putting its front legs on Marion's shoulders, and licks his face. Just then, Cornwallis walks in, overjoyed to see his dogs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jupiter!  Mars! The dogs just look at Cornwallis.  He holds out his arms, waiting for them to rush to him.  They look up at Marion who nods to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go. The dogs run to Cornwallis and nuzzle him in a friendly but not enthusiastic manner.  Cornwallis pats them vigorously, too vigorously for the moderate level of joy the dogs are showing at their reunion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My boys... my boys... you seem to have been well fed.  Thank you for that, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My pleasure, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please forgive me for keeping you waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apology accepted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Colonel... I'm afraid I don't know your name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel will do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you wish. TARLETON ENTERS with four Dragoons, all armed... Marion freezes... Marion and Tarleton lock eyes.  Marion searches for some sign that Tarleton recognizes him.  There's none.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel... Colonel Banastre Tarleton. Tarleton nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel. Marion, like ice, looks Tarleton up and down.  Then he slowly turns and looks at the four Dragoons, two on eithe side of Tarleton.  Marion measures the odds and finds the wanting. With a supreme effort of will, Marion forces himself to turn from Tarleton to Cornwallis and the matter at hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we proceed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us.  Unless you object, I would like to deem this meeting a formal negotiation and, as such, there are certain customary practices. Perhaps I could explain them to you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm familiar with how a formal negotiation is handled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I served in His Majesty's army in the French and Indian War.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.  Very well, then.  Would you, as the initiating party, like to begin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless you would like to claim aggrieved status. Cornwallis is surprised.  He exchanges a look with Tarleton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are familiar with how these things are done.  In fact, I would like to claim aggrieved status.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well, proceed, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First, you have in your possession certain belongings of mine, including clothing, private papers, furniture and personal effects of a non-military nature which I would like to have returned to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will do so as soon as possible. Cornwallis is surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please accept my apology for not having done so sooner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apology accepted.  Now, on the matter of the specific targeting of officers during engagements, this is absolutely unacceptable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That one is a bit more difficult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly you must know that in civilized warfare, officers in the field must not be accorded inappropriate levels of hostile attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what are inappropriate levels of hostile attention?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel, imagine the utter chaos that would result from un-led armies having at each other.  There must be gentlemen in command to lead and, when appropriate, restrain their men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Restrain them from the targeting of civilians, including women and children?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is a separate issue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I consider them linked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg to differ.  One is a command decision on your part.  The other represents nothing more than the occasional over-exuberance of field officers attempting to carry out their duty in difficult circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as your soldiers attack civilians, I will order the shooting of your officers at the outset of every engagement. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And my men are excellent marksmen. Cornwallis sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well, let us move on to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prisoner exchange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have eighteen of my men.  I want them back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do have eighteen criminals under sentence of death, but I hold no prisoners-of-war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that's your position, then eighteen of your officers will die. Nineteen, if you hang me with my men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What officers? Marion steps to the window, checks the view.  A wooded hillside is visible in the distance.  Marion reaches into his jacket... The Dragoons move on him... Marion extracts not a weapon, but a spyglass, which he hands to Cornwallis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the clearing, just down from the crest, to the left of the dark pines... Cornwallis looks through the spyglass.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW THROUGH THE SPYGLASS
dialogues.text: Though difficult to see clearly through the shimmering haze, Cornwallis can just make out a row of bound Redcoat officers, with Patriot soldiers holding muskets at their heads. CORNWALLIS turns coldly to Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their names, ranks and posts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They refused to give me their names. Their ranks are nine lieutenants, five captains, three majors and one fat colonel who called me a cheeky fellow.  Their posts?  We picked them up here-and-there last night. Cornwallis glares at Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are not a gentleman. Marion can't help but laugh at the insult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If your conduct is the measure of a gentleman, I take that as a compliment. (coldly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get my men. Cornwallis turns to Colonel Huntington.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arrange the exchange. Colonel Huntington leaves to do so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, General.  I'm sure your officers will thank you, as well. Marion salutes Cornwallis who doesn't return the salute. THEN MARION TURNS TO TARLETON.  He walks up to him and looks him in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't remember me, do you? Tarleton examines Marion's face, finding him familiar, bu unable to place him... then Tarleton remembers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, yes, that boy. Tarleton calmly holds Marion's glare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugly business, doing one's duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ugly business. Marion takes a step closer to Tarleton, then speaks very softly, very slowly, very clearly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you are alive when this war is over, I'm going to kill you. Marion locks his eyes on Tarleton to make it perfectly clear that he means what he says.  Tarleton tries to cove his reaction but it's apparent that he's taken aback by Marion's icy words. Marion turns and walks out.  The two Great Danes start to follow, but Cornwallis SNAPS A COMMAND:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jupiter!  Mars! THE DOGS FREEZE, looking after Marion, who doesn't turn back.  The dogs reluctantly sidle over to Cornwallis' side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Redcoats glare at Marion who sits, mounted, waiting.  His eighteen men are led out of the prison blockhouse and directed to waiting horses.  Surprised to be freed, they mount up. CORNWALLIS AND TARLETON step out onto the front porch of Cornwallis' headquarters and watch as Marion and his men ride toward the gate. THE TWO GREAT DANES, watch Marion from Cornwallis' side. Cornwallis motions to the Redcoat Sentries to OPEN THE GATES.  They do so and Marion and his men, without hurrying, ride out. Then, just as the gates are closing behind him, Marion, without turning around, lets loose with a PIERCING WHISTLE... THE TWO GREAT DANES INSTANTLY RACE AFTER MARION, making i through the gates just as they're closing. CORNWALLIS, seeing his dogs run after Marion, SPUTTERS, then turns and storms back into his quarters. TARLETON, still off-balance from Marion's parting statement, watches Marion ride away.  Then he turns to Major Wilkins who stands nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a detachment and go get our officers. Wilkins hurries off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major Wilkins and a detachment of Green Dragoons ride up the wooded slope toward the bound Redcoat officers that Cornwallis saw through the spyglass.  As the Dragoons rid out of the trees into the clearing they stop dead, seeing that: THE "REDCOAT OFFICERS" are not real -- they're nothing more than SCARECROWS IN REDCOAT UNIFORMS.  There's no sig of Marion or his men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT:  One of the "Redcoat Officers," stuffed with straw is thrown onto Cornwallis' desk by Tarleton. Cornwallis looks at the scarecrow, then turns to Tarleton

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This fox believes himself clever. We shall see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tarleton and Wilkins wait while Green Dragoons and Loyalists search the remains of Marion's house and barn. Gaskins, filthy from the ashes, walks up to Tarleton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one's been here for months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But now we have a name for our Colonel... Francis Marion.  And with a name will come a family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thick ground fog surrounds Charlotte's house.  The soft lights of candles glow in the windows.  All appears peaceful. Then, the SHADOWED FIGURES of THREE DOZEN GREEN DRAGOONS appear out of the mist, silently approaching the house on foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fire crackles in the fireplace.  A curtain blows in the open window.  THE DOOR BURSTS OPEN.  WINDOWS BREAK.  Gree Dragoons pour into the house, muskets brandished.  No sig of occupants.  CAPTAIN MORROW barks a command:

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS
dialogues.text: The Dragoons THUNDER UP THE STAIRS... Tarleton and Wilkin stride in, watching the search... the parlor... nothing.. The kitchen... food is cooking... The dining room... the table is set, half-eaten food is o the plates, abandoned in mid-meal.  TARLETON WALKS INTO THE DINING ROOM, touches some of the food, gauging its warmth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can't be far.  Check the outbuildings and the woods. The Dragoons race outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TORCH BURNS.  A dozen Dragoons light torches off of it and fan out to search.  The thick fog turns the torches into diffused, floating balls of light, turning the Dragoons into ghost-like apparitions. CAMERA FOLLOWS ONE OF THE TORCHES, carried by a particularly rough-looking Dragoon who skirts the edge of the underbrush closest to the house.  As the torch moves, its flame sends long shadows and shafts of light into the underbrush... The CAMERA STOPS to reveal, in the brush, TWO FACES, GABRIEL AND CHARLOTTE, dark, motionless, watching the search.  Behind them, MARION'S OTHER CHILDREN, Nathan, Samuel, Margaret, William and Susan... Around them, SEVERAL MORE OF MARION'S MEN, including ABNE BROWN, weapons ready.  The moving lights play on their faces. AT THE FRONT OF THE HOUSE, the torches converge, illuminating Tarleton who gives the unheard order.  The torches fan out and begin SETTING FIRE TO THE HOUSE, BARN AND OUTBUILDINGS. MARGARET grips Charlotte's arm.  Gabriel motions and they all ease back, disappearing into the brush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A compound of rude shacks, built of scraps of lumber and rough-hewn logs, stands on the side of the Magpie River. Marion's men wait with the children while Abner, Charlott and Gabriel, flanked by Aaron and Abigail, Marion's middle-aged, black servants, seen in the opening sequence talk with several stern-looking, middle-aged, black FREEDMEN. The conversation, which is out of the children's earshot, is testy, with one of the middle-aged freedmen particularly troubled. Marion's stone-faced children look around, appraising their surroundings, registering the poverty of the shanty town. THE DISCUSSION BETWEEN THE GROWN-UPS ends with a guarded exchange of handshakes.  Gabriel, Charlotte, Abner, Aaron and Abigail rejoin the children and Marion's men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all set. They follow Aaron, down an alley to A SHACK.  Small. Barely standing.  The children stop in their tracks, knowing this is to be their new home. Charlotte sees their hesitation.  She walks up to the little structure, examining it with a critical eye.  She looks on the doorway, seeing a single room, a dirt floor, wax-paper instead of glass in the windows, a rude, chimney-less fire-pit against the back wall.  She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This will do fine. She turns to Aaron and Abigail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Charlotte walks inside without looking back.  The childre hesitate, then follow her inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children help Aaron and Abigail make beds out of armloads of hay.  OUTSIDE, Charlotte and Gabriel talk quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he's the one they talk about, the Swamp Fox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it might be him, the bits and pieces we heard, a veteran, fought in the French and Indian War, knows the swamps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They won't stop looking for you and the children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be alright, here, for now. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is he? Gabriel searches for an honest answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... I'm his son. Gabriel steps over to his saddlebags, opens his pack and pulls out a stack of letters which he hands to Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are for you and the children. They sense someone behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't father come? Gabriel is astonished to hear words coming from his heretofore silent sister.  Charlotte nods, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speaking for months now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't he come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wanted to, Susan, but he couldn't leave his men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He left us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know he did and he's sorry.  He'll come back as soon as he can. Susan says nothing.  Gabriel continues, hopefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are some letters here from him.  Some are just to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care.  I hate him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't hate him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I do.  I hate him and I hope he never comes back. Gabriel kneels down and embraces her.  She stands coldly with her arms at her sides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An astonished Marion talks to Gabriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She spoke?  Susan spoke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full sentences.  As if she had been speaking all along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it... and I wasn't there for it... The cloud passes quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me everything she said, word for word. Gabriel hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said... she loves you and misses you but she understands why you can't be there with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said that?  Oh, my Lord, she said that? Gabriel nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that something. Marion shakes his head at the thought, smiling to himself Gabriel, uncomfortable with the lie, changes the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, there's something else I need to talk to you about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come with me.  I'll tell you when we get there. Marion nods and curiously follows Gabriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark.  The village square is deserted.  Marion follows Gabriel into the shadow of the village church.  They dismount, tie up their horses and enter the back door of the church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion walks in and stops dead.  At the altar of the smal sanctuary, HALF-A-DOZEN PEOPLE stand with Rev. Oliver.  A the center of the tiny gathering is Anne Green, flanked b her parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, I'm looking for a best man. Marion is stunned but recovers quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be honored. They share a moment, then head down the aisle.  Marion greets Anne's parents, shaking hands with her father and bowing to her mother.  Abner, at the door, nods that the coast is clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dearly beloved, we are gathered here in the sight of God to join this man and this woman in holy matrimony... MARION feels every word, looking straight ahead but knowing that he's standing next to his son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the shadows behind the church, the bride and groom say goodbye to the wedding party.  Anne talks quietly with he parents.  Marion and Gabriel talk nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I'd like to request a furlough. Two days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Granted.  Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheraw Falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful there.  Your mother and I were there once, before you were born.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. They're silent for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She would have been pleased. Gabriel nods, then turns to his horse, unnecessarily checking his pack ropes.  Anne joins them.  Marion embraces her and gives her a fatherly kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry we didn't give you more warning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's alright.  I'm very happy for you. He helps her mount up.  Abner, on guard near the road, motions them on.  They all watch as Gabriel and Anne ride off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion, Rev. Oliver and Abner ride slowly down the road. It's a beautiful, moonlit night.  Marion breaks the silence, speaking as much for himself as the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a good measure of a woman that she'll have her honeymoon under the stars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For richer, for poorer, in sickness and in health, 'til death do they part. Marion nods.  They ride on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A British packet, a small, fast warship, lies anchored just offshore.  A rowboat, manned by half-a-dozen sailors carrying a Redcoat Lieutenant, beaches.  Several Redcoats wait. The Lieutenant, carrying a dispatch case, jumps out off the boat, mounts a waiting horse and rides off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cornwallis, with his command staff clustered around him, sits on horseback reading the dispatch as the dispatch rider waits.  They're on a hillside, looking over the burned-out remains of a small British fort as some Redcoats pull the Union Jack out of a trench latrine. Cornwallis motions Tarleton and they ride a few yards fro the other officers and speak, out of earshot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From General Clinton in New York... (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... your request to move north is denied until you have properly dealt with your militia problem." (aside)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He underlined, 'militia'. (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "You have spent over six months dealing with a six-week problem.  It is essential that you quell the militia..." (aside)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Underlined again. (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... insurgency, particularly because of the likely move south of Washington and the inevitable arrival of the French.  Militia, as you have so often pointed out, is not worth the attention of a significant army, hence it is mystifying why militia has bedeviled you for so long..." Tarleton smiles slightly, enjoying the show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... it is my fervent hope that the vigor of your campaign comes to match the vigor of your correspondence with your Parliamentary and Court patrons. Only then might you share in the victory, on the verge of which I now stand." (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Your guardedly respectful Commander, General Sir George Clinton." Cornwallis grows eerily calm and turns to Tarleton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I fail, you fail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if I triumph, you triumph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can we end this madness?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Difficult, sir.  This is, as you pointed out, a civil war. Cornwallis takes a moment, then speaks simply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Civility is a secondary virtue.  It is superseded by duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand, sir. Tarleton salutes, yanks his reins, turning his horse, and rides off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tarleton lounges in the grass on a slope in front of a farmhouse, looking out at a lovely sunset, absentmindedly picking at the petals of some wildflowers.  A HIDEOUS SCREAM pierces the calm. Tarleton analytically evaluates the tenor of the scream, then rises, passing several Green Dragoons who wait with their horses in front of the farmhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe they are almost ready.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE FARMHOUSE
dialogues.text: Blood is smeared on one wall, where half-a-dozen corpses lie in a jumbles mass on the floor. In the parlor, Tarleton walks past more bodies, including a dead woman who lies protectively but ineffectually over the bloody bodies of her two young children, both under eight-years-old. In the kitchen, Tarleton finds Wilkins, some Green Dragoons, and Gaskins, the Loyalist Militia commander and some of his low-life men. Rob Fielding, one of the craftsmen in Marion's force, is tied, spread-eagle to the table, showing the terrible effects of PROTRACTED TORTURE.  Wilkins and Gaskins are nervous and apologetic as Tarleton walks into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir.  He died. Tarleton sighs, irritated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well, get one of the others. Gaskins and a couple of his men step into an attached woodshed where Billings sits, bound.  They roughly grab him and drag him into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn your eyes.  Do your worst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I intend to. They tie Billings to the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.  A tiny rivulet of blood runs along a plank in the floor, disappearing into a gap between two floorboards. Marion, Dalton, Rev. Oliver, and several other men walk slowly through the farmhouse, in stunned silence. Marion sees the body of the mother, draped over her two young children.  Marion turns to Rev. Oliver who can only stare, offering no solace. They pass Fielding's body, then enter the kitchen and see BILLINGS, DEAD, still tied to the table.  Marion reels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion's men dig graves.  Marion watches.  Dalton steps u next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still want me to give wounded Redcoats quarter? Marion doesn't answer.  Gabriel GALLOPS up.  He reins bac his lathered horse and speaks to them without dismounting

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tarleton has a list of our men, most are on it.  A regiment of dragoons is going to the homes on the list, burning them, killing whomever resists, women and children, as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven homes along the Black River so far... Rollins doesn't pause.  He rushes to his horse, mounts up and rides off.  Marion and the other men mount up and rid off fast after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion his brigade catch up to Rollins and ride on with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The small farm seen earlier, surrounded by hills, where the two boys, Rollins' sons ran down the hillside to catc a glimpse of the passing Marion and his brigade. The house smolders.  No sign of life.  Gabriel, Abner and a few other men warily ride the perimeter of the cleared area around the house. Marion, at the head of the rest of the brigade, waits nex to an increasingly frantic, Rollins.  They see Gabriel wave, signaling all clear. MARION, ROLLINS AND THE OTHER MEN RIDE to the house. Rollins is the first to see THE BODIES.  Horrified, he reins back and dismounts, almost falling. His TWO SONS, WIFE, an OLDER MAN and WOMAN, lie dead in the dirt.  Marion's men silently watch Rollins' agony. Weeping and confused, he moves in a mad, staccato manner, as if he were a marionette, whose strings were being jerked by a drunken puppeteer. Marion and Rev. Oliver dismount and move toward him. Rollins sees them coming.  He hardens and strides to his horse, pulling his FLINTLOCK PISTOL from his saddle holster. Rev. Oliver reaches out to embrace Rollins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not time for vengeance, it's time to mourn and...

dialogues.speaker: BLOWING HIS BRAINS OUT.
dialogues.text: Every man freezes in place.  For a long moment no one moves, no one speaks.  Then Marion pulls himself together and addresses the men:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five day furlough for all men. Abner, Dan, Reverend, spread the word.  We'll reform at Acworth.  Any man who doesn't come back won't be thought a coward or uncommitted to the cause.  Attend to your families. The men mount up.  Marion and Gabriel ride off together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion scans the night as Gabriel and Anne mount up.  The three of them ride off, pulling a line of horses, some heavily loaded packhorses and some saddled but empty mounts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark.  Quiet.  Gabriel and Anne wait in the shadows while Marion cocks his musket, checks his pistols and walks slowly toward the shack. He warily checks every shadow.  No one anywhere.  Then a SOUND -- A SQUEAL OF LAUGHTER, immediately followed by:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's him!  I told you it was him! MARION'S CHILDREN RACE OUT OF THE SHADOWS to Marion.  He' practically bowled over as Margaret, Nathan, Samuel and William fling themselves into his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa... CHARLOTTE STEPS OUT OF THE SHADOWS, watching the reunion as Marion covers the children with kisses, trying to hug all of them at once as they cling to him as if they'll never let go.  MARION AND CHARLOTTE LOCK EYES over the heads of the children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Charlotte smiles.  Then Marion notices SUSAN peeking out from behind Charlotte's patched and mended skirt.  He kneels down and opens his arms to her but she doesn't move. He smiles to her and speaks softly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan... She looks coldly at Marion, tightens her grip on Charlotte's skirt and retreats further behind her.  Mario looks to Charlotte who nods with guarded reassurance. Then his attention is drawn away by the demanding embrace of his other children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion rides, leading his children, Charlotte and Anne up a steep, narrow path that cuts through a heavily wooded hillside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The remains of a tiny abandoned backcountry farm.  The house is gone, leaving only an overgrown cellar hole. Nearby is a barely-standing tobacco shed, one end of whic has fallen to the ground.  A SOFT WIND WHISTLES AND WHISPERS through the gaps in the rough-hewn boards of the structure. Marion rides up to the edge of the clearing.  A MOCKINGBIRD SCREECHES nearby, startling him.  He looks back at the children, worried, anticipating a negative reaction.  Margaret smiles and turns to the other children, speaking for Marion's benefit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, things would get better. The children smile and dismount.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POURING RAIN.  The ceiling drips.  Marion lies, awake, with his children huddled against him, sleeping in one of the few dry spots.  They're covered with tattered quilts. On the other side of the children, Charlotte is also awake.  She and Marion exchange a long, silent look in th darkness, over the heads of the sleeping children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion walks the perimeter of their encampment with Natha and Samuel.  They listen carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The overlook, up there should be where you post the watch.  Work out a schedule.  Short watches, especially at night. (pointing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you can catch some of those mockingbirds you can make cages and put them along there for alarms. (motioning for them to follow)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let's find someplace to cache extra weapons... They follow Marion like soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion sits on a rock while Margaret cuts his hair.  She takes her time, touching him on the head and shoulders, extending the process.  Marion, sits back, enjoying it. He notices Susan, nearby, watching silently.  He smiles. She turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark.  Shafts of light shine in through the holes in the roof.  Marion, standing in the shadows, senses someone coming.  He freezes. A figure rounds the corner.  It's... William.  MARION YELLS William SQUEALS IN DELIGHT, then chases his father around the corner, tagging him.  They laugh.  Marion covers his eyes and William dashes off to hide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion sits on the side of the river with Susan who avoid looking at him.  Using the knife we've seen him use in battle he cuts slices off an apple and eats them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good apple. No response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
