dialogues.text: Very good.  Sweet. He cuts a slice and offers it to her.  She doesn't take it.  He puts the slice between them.  After a long moment she picks it up but as she's about to eat it, she stops, seeing something on it.  She puts it back. Marion looks at the apple slice and sees a dark red splotch on it.  He looks at his knife and realizes that it's dried blood. Off-balance, he turns to Susan who stares straight ahead, a thousand miles from Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion washes the knife carefully, almost obsessively. Anne steps up behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I ask you a question? Marion finishes with the knife and puts it away without explanation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. She speaks with a sly, withheld smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think Frances with an "e" is too manly a name for a girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think Francis with an "i" is too womanly a name for a boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Anne smiles and walks away.  Marion figures out what she just told him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late summer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Marion laughs at the thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion's children swim and play with the two Great Danes in the pond at the base of the falls, along with Gabriel and Anne.  Marion and Charlotte sit on the bank, watching them. Charlotte turns and looks at Marion for a long moment. He's unaware.  As Charlotte looks at him, her smile disappears, replaced by anger.  She snaps at Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not my sister. Startled, Marion turns to Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, I'm not my sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well, then. She turns from him.  Marion, tries to figure out what jus happened.  After a long moment he gets it.  Stunned at first, his gears turn.  After a very thoughtful moment he turns to Charlotte and offers a tentative smile.  She rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark.  A full moon shines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion wakes.  He looks across his sleeping children and sees that Charlotte isn't in her place on the other side of them.  He rises and walks out into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion walks into the glen.  He tenses, sensing someone i front of him.  Then he sees CHARLOTTE AT THE EDGE OF THE WOODS.  Neither one speaks... They walk silently to each other.  They stop, looking at each other closely, as if seeing one another for the firs time... Only then do they kiss.  The kiss grows more passionate.. then much more passionate...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion finishes tying his gear onto his horse.  The children are silent.  He stands beside his horse.  One after another, the children walk to him and embrace him - Nathan, Samuel, Margaret, William. He sees Susan, standing next to Charlotte.  He motions to her but she doesn't move.  Then he kneels down and gently hugs her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a little goodbye?  One word? That's all I want to hear. Susan remains silent, standing with her arms at her sides not responding to the embrace. Finally, Marion lets go of her.  She just stares at him. Marion stands and turns to Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye. They embrace.  Though the hug is chaste, their eyes tell different story.  Only Anne and Margaret notice, but to them it's as clear as a bell.  They exchange a knowing look. Marion and Charlotte break apart, self-consciously. Marion and Gabriel mount up and start to ride away.  As they're about to round a curve and disappear, SUSAN CRIES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa! With halting steps, then faster and faster, she runs down the path toward Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa, don't go, I'll say anything. Marion stops, turning in his saddle to see Susan running after him, her eyes filled with tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Papa, I'll say anything you want! Marion yanks his reins, turning his horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just tell me what to say!  Tell me what to say! Marion spurs his horse straight toward her, GALLOPING toward the running, crying child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Papa, please don't go. MARION RIDES TOWARD HER... Charlotte, Anne and Marion's children watch as: MARION LEANS OVER IN THE SADDLE without slowing down... SWOOPING HER INTO HIS LAP... She sits astride the saddle, facing him, her arms wrapped around him, pleading, the words tumbling from her, as fas as she can get them out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I'll talk to you, I'll say anything you want, just tell me what you want me to say, I'll say anything, I promise, please, Papa, just stay... Marion envelopes the sobbing wisp of a girl, holding her, letting her cry, fighting his own tears... He reins back the horse, stopping in front of the others... He pleadingly looks to Charlotte who steps up to the horse... to take Susan... Marion gives Susan a final embrace, and covers her face with kisses...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll come back... I promise... Marion hands the still crying Susan down to Charlotte... Marion, in agony, averts his eyes, yanks his reins, and spurs his horse... As he rides away the children take off after him, running Susan seeing the others running after Marion, struggles out of Charlotte's arms, and runs after them as well... Marion rides, now joined by Gabriel, faster and faster, leaving a trail of dust... The children slow, then stop, one after another, watching as they ride away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grim.  The most rudimentary of the encampments we've seen Rain pours.  Some of Marion's men huddle under lean-to's and quickly rigged tents that offer only partial protection from the cold rain. Abner and Scott do their best to keep a wet-wood fire going.  Rev. Oliver tries to cook. Marion and Gabriel ride up and dismount.  Marion joins Rev. Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many came back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About a hundred and twenty.  Less than a third. Marion nods.  He and Gabriel join some of the men under one of the lean-to's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain has stopped.  The ground is still wet.  It's spring.  The first buds are on the maple trees.  A fox tentatively comes out of its winter den, followed by a pair of pups. Marion stands on the side of a river, looking up at a chevron of Canadian geese flying north.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Canadian Geese fly over Anne who is behind her father's store, tying food and provisions to a couple of packhorses.  A mare and a foal cavort in a nearby paddock Suddenly Anne senses someone behind her and turns to see HALF-A DOZEN REDCOATS.  She's initially frightened but th REDCOAT SERGEANT, speaks politely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Ma'am, everyone has been requested to gather at the church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Tarleton wants to address, the whole village. The Redcoat Sergeant deferentially motions for Anne to follow him and his men.  She sees several other townspeople, with Redcoat escorts, already heading down the street.  She follows along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tarleton and Wilkins, on horseback, watch as a large, mixed detachment of Green Dragoons and Redcoat Infantry directs the villagers into the church. One of the Redcoats walks out of the general store with a bowl of gumdrops.  As he starts giving them to a few of the children their parents waver, unsure of the gesture, but they reluctantly allow the children to take the candy The townspeople are uneasy but they follow the orders of the Redcoats who, though carry muskets, are polite and unthreatening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Into the church, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Tarleton wishes to address all of you. Tarleton sees the last of the townspeople enter the church.  He nods to the Redcoats near the door. The Redcoats CLOSE THE DOORS, chaining them shut.  The DOOR IS POUNDED ON from the inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open this door!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By what right are we made prisoners? TARLETON NODS TO GASKINS who, along with several rough- looking LOYALIST MILITIAMEN, disappear into the blacksmit shop.  They reappear a moment later with FLAMING TORCHES and approach the church. Several Redcoats see what's about to happen and are appalled.  Even some of the Green Dragoons, including Wilkins, are troubled.  Wilkins rides over to Tarleton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Major. Gaskins and the Loyalist Militia stop around the church, torches ready, waiting for the final go-ahead from Tarleton.  The POUNDING AND CALLING from inside the churc grows louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, there is no honor in this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The honor is found in the end, not the means.  This will be forgotten. (to Gaskins)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Proceed. The Redcoats turn to the Redcoat Officers.  The Redcoat officers turn to Wilkins, who struggles with himself. Tarleton calmly watches Wilkins' distress. Finally, Wilkins accepts it.  Weakly steadying his horse, he takes his place next to Tarleton. The Redcoats and Dragoons follow his lead and watch as Gaskins and the Loyalist Militiamen light the church on fire, heaving their torches onto the roof, through the windows and under the raised foundation. SCREAMS are heard from inside.  The DOOR THUDS with the shoulders of men trying to escape.  The CHAINS HOLD. As the FLAMES RISE, another group of Loyalist Militiamen and some Redcoats drag half-a-dozen young women out of a side-street... Among the women, desperately pleading, kicking and screaming, is ANNE... The men drag her and the other women into the livery stable... Tarleton watches them carried off, stone-faced... Then he turns and watches the church go up in FLAMES... A WINDOW SHATTERS, with a chair heaved from inside... SOME MEN TRY TO CLIMB OUT, but waiting Redcoats FIRE THEI MUSKETS POINT BLANK... KILLING THREE MEN, driving the others back... The SCREAMS FROM INSIDE THE CHURCH grow louder... The FLAMES AND SMOKE RISE...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SILENCE.  A dark forest of old growth trees.  No underbrush.  Marion and a couple dozen of his men, including Gabriel, Rev. Oliver, and Dalton ride warily on a carpet of pine needles toward a thin column of smoke, visible over the treetops in the distance. With hand signals, Marion directs his men to fan out. They do so, weaving through the dark forest, weapons ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion and his men slowly ride into Pembroke.  The remain of the church smolder only slightly.  The town is deserted, no one, dead or alive, is visible. Unsure what they have found, Marion and his men spread ou and dismount, warily checking out the buildings, looking for some sign of life. Rev. Oliver and a few other men head for the charred remains of the church. Side-stepping some still-hot, charred beams, Rev. Oliver looks through the rubble... Then he sees the bodies... THE CAMERA CATCHES ONLY A FLEETING GLIMPSE of... Dozens of charred, blackened bodies, intertwined with the remains of the church... Rev. Oliver staggers from the rubble... The other men see what he has seen... One-by-one Marion and his men walk over and look into the remains of the church... Marion see several charred hands extended through a shattered window, as if grasping for escape... one of the hands is tiny, A CHILD'S HAND... Marion is stunned... No one says a word... Dalton and a few of the other men continue the search, weapons ready... They step into the livery stable, then walk out a moment later, ashen faced... Dalton speaks quietly to Marion, motioning toward an increasingly frantic Gabriel who has just found Anne's packhorses... Gabriel notices the gesture, he watches Marion walk into the livery stable... Growing more nervous by the second, Gabriel hurries after his father...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne...? As Gabriel gets to the entrance of the livery stable, Marion walks out and intercepts him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it her?  Is Anne in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is.  Don't go in there. Gabriel understands... he reels... growing faint... Mario grabs him... keeping him from falling... Marion holds Gabriel who begins to weep...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion's men, led by Rev. Oliver, tend to the dead.  Some dig in the small graveyard adjacent to the remains of the church.  Others carry out the grim task of pulling the charred bodies out of the rubble.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE EDGE OF TOWN
dialogues.text: Marion sits alone.  Gabriel walks up behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, tell me what happened at Fort Wilderness?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone knows.  It's what made me a hero.  Me, Harry Lee, all of us.  I got a medal.  Men bought me drinks. They still do sometimes.  Everyone knows what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me what everyone doesn't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do they know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That the French and Cherokees captured the fort and when you retook it, you took revenge on them for what they did during the occupation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not enough.  Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother asked me the same question around the time you were born.  I was drunk and I was foolish enough to answer her. Marion shakes his head to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why it was four years between you and Thomas.  It took me that long to regain her respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not my mother.  I can't have the respect without the knowing. Marion's quiet for a moment.  Then he speaks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was in '63.  It was a bad time. The French and the Cherokee had raided along the Blue Ridge.  All the English settlers took refuge at Fort Wilderness but the French captured it.  We were sent in relief.  Harry Lee, Billings, sixty of us.  We already had something of a reputation for being... harsh. When we got there the fort was abandoned.  Not a French soldier or Cherokee anywhere.  They had left a week earlier.  What we found was... bad. Marion grows quieter with the memory of how bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They had left the settlers there. The men had been burned alive, the women were in pieces and the children were on stakes. Marion's silent for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We buried them, then we went to track.  It was a cold trail and they were moving fast.  We went faster. We caught up to them at Kentucky Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We took our time with them and gave every one of them worse than they had given at the fort.  It was two weeks before they were all dead, all except two.  We put the heads on a pallet and had the two we let live take it to the French at Fort Ambercon. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The eyes, fingers and tongues we put in a basket and sent that down the Asheulot to the Cherokee. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The French stayed east of the Blue Ridge after that and the Cherokee broke their treaty with the French and stayed out of the fight. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That seemed to make a difference. The war went another year, things went better... and men bought us drinks. Gabriel is silent.  Marion looks at him closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a different time, son.  And you're a better man than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see, do as I say, not as I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. They hear HORSES HOOVES.  Abner rides in from the opposit side of the village from the church, not having seen the results of the massacre.  Excited, he dismounts.

dialogues.speaker: HERE
dialogues.text: Marion and Gabriel just look at him.  Abner is confused b their reaction.  Then he sees the remains of the church and the laid out, charred bodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mixed gatherings of Marion's militia and Continentals are clustered around the campfires, with more Continentals arriving all the time. Some of the militiamen and regulars regale each other wit tales of their exploits but most are grim and tired, talking quietly. A couple of Patriots play a MELANCHOLY TUNE ON FIFE AND VIOLIN. Marion's tent is set up but he's nowhere to be seen. Gabriel walks to Marion's gear.  Finding Marion's weapon' belt he opens one of the bullet pouches and finds the paint-flecked MUSKET BALLS MADE FROM THOMAS' LEAD SOLDIERS.  As Gabriel takes one, Marion steps up behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this war is about more than Thomas, it's about more than Anne, as well.  Stay the course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you did at Fort Wilderness? Before Marion can answer they see HARRY LEE RIDE UP TO THEM.  He dismounts, excited, voluble.  He strides over, pleased to see Marion, oblivious to his and Gabriel's mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at you!  I knew you could do it! Lee laughs, picks up a bottle and takes a big pull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a chance!  Better than a chance!  Cornwallis is running to the Chesapeake, probably to meet his fleet at Yorktown.  I wish I could see his face when he sees a dozen French ships floating there.  And Washington should be a day or two behind him. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And on top of everything, I have a son!  Born last month in Alexandria. Gabriel rises and walks away.  Lee finally tunes into the pall hanging over Marion and the just departed Gabriel. He turns to Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His wife was killed yesterday.  She was with child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I didn't know. Marion nods.  They stand in silence.  Lee hands Marion th bottle.  He takes a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark.  Quiet.  Sentries are on duty.  Marion's tent glows from a single candle.  He blows the candle out, then step out of the tent into the night. He begins his nightly walk of the perimeter. Almost immediately, Marion notices something amiss. Dalton has discovered it at the same time and hurries ove to Marion.

dialogues.speaker: AT ONE OF THE CAMPSITES
dialogues.text: Marion and Dalton and several of the other men look down at some empty bedrolls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabriel and at least a dozen others. They must have left right after the watch change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That means they have two hours on us. Marion strides to his horse.  The other men follow him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion, Dalton and Rev. Oliver and two dozen other men ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark.  Very quiet.  A moonless night.  Marion and his men on foot, make their way along the side of the river. Brother Joseph hurries out of the darkness and speaks to Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty Green Dragoons, camped about a quarter mile from here.  Sentries at four points. Suddenly they hear the SOUNDS OF MUSKETS FIRE ahead of them in the darkness.  Marion takes off at a full run wit his men right behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion and his men BLAST THROUGH THE BRUSH.  Running toward the SOUNDS OF THE BATTLE, which grows louder with every step... Marion cocks his pistol and extracts his tomahawk on the run... The LIGHTS OF THE BATTLE:  The STROBES OF THE MUSKET SHOT illuminate the woods ahead of them... Moving fast, they PASS TWO DEAD BRITISH SENTRIES, without slowing down... THEY BLAST OUT OF THE WOODS into... THE CLEARING, seeing a tableau of TOTAL CHAOS: Half-dressed GREEN DRAGOONS in formation FIRE IN VOLLEYS... Running men.  Scattered MUSKET FIRE. The strobes of the muskets illuminate RUNNING MEN and other men in HAND-TO-HAND COMBAT. WILKINS IS IN COMMAND.  Tarleton is nowhere to be seen. Gabriel and Abner, both slightly wounded, fight a desperate holding action... On the other side of the clearing, a square of Dragoons forms near Wilkins.

dialogues.speaker: FIRE
dialogues.text: The DRAGOONS FIRE A MASSED VOLLEY, hitting Gabriel, Abner and several other Patriots. GABRIEL, BADLY WOUNDED, falls to his knees... The Dragoons pull their pistols about to fire again. Marion and his men OPEN FIRE... Staggering them... Marion sees Wilkins about to fire at Gabriel... Marion runs... Sees another Redcoat about to fire at Gabriel... MARION KILLS HIM with a pistol shot. Wilkins cocks his flintlock pistol, aims at Gabriel... MARION'S ABOUT TO THROW HIS TOMAHAWK... TOO LATE... WILKINS FIRES... HITTING GABRIEL WHO FLIES BACKWARD... Marion THROWS THE TOMAHAWK, sinking it into Wilkins' chest... The rest of Marion's men thunder into the Dragoons... Overpowering them... Marion races to Gabriel... Throws himself onto the ground next to him... Cradling him... Gabriel is stunned, confused by the wounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm alright, I... He tries to stand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me help you... Gabriel weakens in Marion's arms... falters... Marion watches the life drain from Gabriel... He tries to hold the blood in, to no avail... Dalton plants himself next to Marion, defending him and Gabriel... Marion caresses Gabriel and watches as... GABRIEL DIES. The life drains from Marion.  No anger.  Only pain.  He looks at Gabriel, lost in a dream, an incomprehensible nightmare of loss and overwhelming emptiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion's men finish laying out the bodies of their dead. The Dragoons are still where they fell.  The Patriots are laid out in a row, their faces covered by their coats. Marion sits on the battlefield, next to Gabriel's body. Dalton gingerly approaches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel... Marion slowly stands and picks up Gabriel's body, cradlin him like a child.  They head off into the brush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More Continentals have arrived, now outnumbering Marion's men three-to-one.  The encampment is active.  A few of th men drink and TALK LOUDLY.  The two men playing the fife and violin PLAY A MORE VIBRANT TUNE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark.  Shadowed.  The sounds of celebration can be heard outside the tent. Marion sits on his camp chair.  Gabriel lies on the groun carefully covered up to his chin with a blanket.  A singl candle burns. Rev. Oliver enters the tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I help you try to find solace with the word of God? No response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel, let us help his soul find it's place with the Almighty and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks as if he's sleeping, doesn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, he does. Rev. Oliver pulls up a camp stool.  He and Marion sit in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Patriots, Continentals and Militia, are moving out. Most of the tents have been taken down.  Wagons are rolling out.  Companies of Continentals march off in good order. MARION'S TENT still stands.  His men finish packing up, storing their heavy gear in wagons, tying their field gea onto their horses.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE TENT
dialogues.text: Marion still sits.  A FLY BUZZES.  Gabriel's face has taken on a deathly, ashen look. Lee enters the tent.  He's silent for a moment, then speaks softly to Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to bury him. No response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll help you bury him. Lee moves toward Gabriel's body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't touch him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many men have we seen die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two.  Gabriel and Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're gone.  And there is nothing you or I can do to bring them back. But there is something you can do to help end all this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is ended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  It's not over yet.  Two days ride, Yorktown, Virginia. Washington, the French, Cornwallis and Tarleton.  It will end, one way or another. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francis, nothing will replace your sons but helping us will justify their sacrifice. Marion doesn't respond.  Lee waits for a long moment, the he hears the SOUND OF THE DEPARTING TROOPS OUTSIDE THE TENT. He looks at Marion, touches him on the shoulder and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last of the soldiers move out, leaving their smoldering campfires and refuse.  The only tent that remains is Marion's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion sits in his tent, gazing obliquely at Gabriel's body which has grown even more ashen.  A SOLITARY BIRD CRIES in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark, moonless night.  The sky is filled with stars.  A SOFT WIND BLOWS dead leaves along the ground.  A few of the leaves are blown through the opening of Marion's tent

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE TENT
dialogues.text: Marion looks down, noticing the leaves, HEARING THE WIND. He listens for a moment.  Then he stands and walks out of the tent.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE TENT
dialogues.text: Marion watches the leaves skittering along the ground.  H listens to the wind. The HE LOOKS UP AT THE NIGHT SKY.  The stars are bright. His eyes are drawn to the Big Dipper and from there to th Little Dipper and the... NORTH STAR. Holding his eyes on the faint, but steady star, he gradually reorients himself.  He looks around at the abandoned encampment.  Then he looks into the tent and sees Gabriel's body.  The SOFT WIND BLOWS AROUND HIM. Marion nods in response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion finishes burying Gabriel, putting the last shovelfuls of dirt on the freshly turned earth.  He stand next to the grave, looking down, and says a silent prayer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The AMERICAN FORCES are on the move, all heading in the same direction.  Continentals and militiamen fill the road.  Some on horseback, others in wagons, most on foot. Among them, a mixed unit of Continentals and Marion's brigade, at the head of which ride Lee, Dalton, Abner and Rev. Oliver. Behind them, a single horseman rides up.  It's MARION. Without speaking, Marion rides up alongside Lee.  They exchange nods. Marion rides between Dalton on one side and Rev. Oliver o the other.  They pass a sign that reads, "Yorktown.  20 miles."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The road to Yorktown skirts an OVERLOOK with a view of th town and the harbor.  A few dozen arriving Patriots have stopped to look out at the view.  Marion, Lee, Rev. Olive and Dalton join them. The French Fleet is visible in the harbor.  The British encampments are on a pair of peninsulas, one jutting out from land, the other jutting toward the land from a large island.  In a semi-circle around the landward peninsula, the beginnings of the Patriot encirclement are visible. It's a grand and impressive sight. Marion and the others turn their horses and head down the road toward the American lines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN INTERMITTENT EXCHANGE OF CANNON FIRE.  Not a battle, but pre-battle pot shots.  Behind the American embattlements, hundreds of American and French soldiers drill, make camp and build secondary fortifications. MARION, stands behind a barricade, trying to get a view o the British defenses.  A RUNNER, a boy about fifteen, dashes up to Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You called for me, sir? Marion reaches into his pocket and pulls out a single WALNUT which he hands to the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take this to General Washington. The boy looks at the walnut and then looks at Marion as i he's joking or crazy.  He's neither.  The boy shrugs and runs off with the walnut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staff officers.  Flags.  Tents.  French and American officers look over maps and sort out dispatches. Messengers, runners and dispatch riders come and go hurriedly. The flap of the central HQ tent opens and GEORGE WASHINGTON steps out, followed by a pair of AIDES. Washington is tall and powerfully-built, an imposing man, worthy of respect. He looks around and sees the awe-struck, slightly confuse messenger boy, waiting nearby. Washington, holding the walnut in his hand, motions him over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you bring me this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Washington scribbles something on a piece of paper and hands it to the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take this to Colonel Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. The boy runs off.  Washington smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA FOLLOWS Marion walking through the chaos of the encampment.  He walks to the cluster of tents around Washington's HQ.  He nods to the officer in charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Francis Marion. Washington, leaning over the maps on his campaign table, hears the voice and turns around.  The officers nearby stop and watch, curious.

dialogues.speaker: MARION AND WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Step up to one another, looking each other in the eye. To the astonishment of Washington's officers, Marion reaches up and lifts off Washington's wig, looking at his hair underneath.  Marion shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Earned. Washington holds out a small bag to Marion who reaches in and pulls out a walnut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come.  I have something I want to show you. Washington turns to his staff officers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen. Washington and Marion walk off with Washington's officers and aides.As Washington and Marion walk, they both CRUSH

dialogues.speaker: THE WALNUTS SHELLS BETWEEN THEIR THUMBS AND FOREFINGERS,
dialogues.text: prodigious display of strength that both men take for granted.  They eat walnuts as they walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Washington's officers who include HARRY LEE, COLONEL ALEXANDER HAMILTON, LAFAYETTE, GENERAL PINKNEY, and various other aides and junior officers reach the crest o the hill and wait for Washington and Marion who trail a bit behind them, talking privately, eating walnuts as the go. While they wait, the officers look out at the view, seein the PUFFS OF SMOKE OF INTERMITTENT CANNON FIRE.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON AND MARION
dialogues.text: Finish the walnuts.  They stop for a moment to catch thei breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was sorry to hear about your son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lost another a year ago, Thomas. He was only fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had no sons to lose, nor daughters. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lose the sons of other men. They look out at the vista, knowing that they're looking at the sons of thousands and thousands of other men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life was easier when we only had ourselves to get killed. They walk on, joining the others on the crest of the hill The officers are looking out, some with spyglasses, at the British emplacements.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, what do we see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mortars, center, with two lines of enfilading trenches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More along the right flank and behind the forward redoubts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A formidable defensive position. Very formidable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They could hold out for weeks. Washington nods and turns to Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francis, tell me about General Cornwallis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember Braddock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Proud, priggish and competent.  A very bad combination in an adversary. Washington sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For those of you who don't know, we intercepted a British dispatch this morning.  General Clinton has sailed from New York to relieve Cornwallis. That hits Washington's officers hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long before they arrive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Less than a week.  Sixteen ships and over nine thousand Redcoats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sooner or later that message will get through to Cornwallis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when it does, he'll just wait us out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when the British ships arrive, the French ships will flee.  And when the French ships flee, General Rochambeau and the French troops will flee as well. Marion speaks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you must let the message go through. They all turn to Marion, most of them looking at him as i he's insane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Cornwallis receives news that Clinton is coming, he'll simply hold tight and wait.  He'll fight a purely defensive battle and he'll win that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he won't.  There are two things you need to know about Cornwallis. First, he is a very proud man, He would rather risk defeat than share a victory. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you give him what he thinks is an out, he'll take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what is the second thing? Marion pulls Cornwallis' journal out of his haversack and leafs through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll let him tell you himself... (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... but it is this colonial militia that is the most irksome.  Not worthy of my attention, but demanding it; not worthy of British blood, but taking it; and not worthy of a soldier's honor, but sullying it.  Those nights of mine that are not sleepless, are filled with dreams of a cavalry charge on the heels of fleeing farmers..." Marion closes the journal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has no respect for citizen soldiers.  That's your bait... militia. Washington nods, considering it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under fire.  Cornwallis and his staff.  Major Halbert strides in and gives Cornwallis a dispatch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, a dispatch from General Clinton made it through the rebel lines. Cornwallis takes the dispatch and reads it.  It staggers him.  He sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir? Cornwallis fumes.  His jaw sets with anger.  He slowly crumples the dispatch and speaks with quiet fury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call a general staff meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion stands at the American battlements, looking out at the British defensive works.  Above him, stars are visible, but they're fading in the light of the pre-dawn glow from the horizon. Marion scans the disappearing stars, searching out the NORTH STAR, but in the increasingly harsh light of this day, he can't find it.  He turns his eyes back to the battlefield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun has risen but a heavy ground fog limits visibilit to a few dozen yards.  Men move like ghosts. THE CAMERA finds waiting squadrons of men but in the mist There is no overview, just separate detachments: An orderly regiment of CONTINENTAL CAVALRY, mounted, waiting, steadying their horses. Two long lines of CONTINENTAL INFANTRY RESERVES... An American Command, including Washington, LaFayette and two dozen staff officers, attended by riders and runners... And, finally, MARION AND HIS MEN, who stand in the middle of a long line of Patriot militia in the center of a long valley-line depression. They stand silently, unable to see anything other than each other and the gently slope of the dew-covered grass in front of them. They're all grim.  They know what's coming. Then, the SOUND OF A SINGLE DRUM, heard but unseen, comin from over the slope... Then, MORE DRUMS, more and more, A COMPETITION OF DRUM BEATS... Marion's men listen, turning their heads, trying to imagine what is happening on the other side of the rise i front of them. MARION MOTIONS FOR HIS OFFICERS, Dalton, Scott, Rev. Oliver and several other Patriot militia officers from other units.  They quickly gather around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The British army believes in officers.  I believe in soldiers. After we engage, there will be no more orders.  Every man here must know what I'm about to tell you. They listen closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are the bait in a trap.  We're militia.  Cornwallis thinks we're rabble, nothing more than a bunch of undisciplined farmers.  And if he thinks that's what we are, that's what we're going to give him. Listen up. They gather around closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cornwallis, surrounded by his staff officers, including Tarleton, stands on a low hill, trying, with the aid of a spyglass to catch the first view of the battlefield as th morning mist begins to burn off. Through the fog, he just makes out the American lines.  H turns to Tarleton who also peers through a spyglass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you see that, Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless I'm dreaming, I think I see irregulars at their center. Cornwallis and Tarleton exchange a pleased look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion and his men wait. A STRANGE SOUND.  Soft, muted.  The men turn their heads, listening, their eyes shifting. They hear the SOUND OF THOUSANDS OF BOOTS ON WET GRASS, advancing... THE CAMERA WATCHES THE FACES OF MARION AND HIS MEN as the listen to an unseen army approaching. ON MARION'S FACE we see him hearing every sound and we se FLASH CUTS of what he knows he's hearing: The BOOTS OF THE UNSEEN SOLDIERS... Shouldered muskets CLICKING against pack buckles... SILENCE at a stop... MORE DRUMS... The men around Marion wait. THEN, THEY SEE IT... A MASSIVE WALL OF RED appears over the rise in front of them... Thousands of Redcoats, in perfect formation, marching in lockstep, straight for them. Marion sees the fear on his men's faces, but none of them move... The BRITISH DRUMS GROW LOUDER AND LOUDER... it's almost enough to drive a man to flight... almost. The CAMERA explores the faces of Marion's men, faces that we know, Rev. Oliver, Scott, Abner, Marion.  All are frightened but all are motionless. Closer and closer, the British line approaches... The American's don't move... Then, the BRITISH LINE STOPS... At a flurry of commands, the Redcoats ready their muskets then aim... Still, Marion and the Americans don't move... DEAD SILENCE... Then, a single, thin voice calls out from the British lines... IN A THUNDEROUS, MASSIVE VOLLEY, three thousand British muskets fire simultaneously... just as the entire line of AMERICAN MILITIAMEN DIVE TO THE GROUND... Many Americans are saved by the move but many, many other are torn apart by the British musketballs... THE AMOUNT OF SMOKE IS INCREDIBLE... it obscures everything.  Each musket spits out a billow of think whit smoke a dozen feet in front of it and three thousand of them just fired.  The massive, opaque white cloud quickly spreads over the entire battlefield. The astonished Redcoats instantly reload... And watch as the Americans rise in DISORDERLY PANIC and FLEE... Some Redcoats laugh... ON A RISE BEHIND THE BATTLEFIELD, CORNWALLIS, watches through his spyglass, trying to get a sense of what's happening before the spreading cloud of musket smoke obscures everything. He barks to his SIGNALMAN...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fix bayonets... dispatch the Green Dragoons. The Signalman raises his semaphore flags and snaps the message. MARION AND HIS MEN are caught in the middle of the chaoti retreat... THE BRITISH LINE advances at a quickstep, bayonets fixed... From behind them, THE GREEN DRAGOONS appear, at a full gallop, Tarleton at their head...

dialogues.speaker: THE BATTLEFIELD
dialogues.text: It's an astonishing sight... total madness... hell... a painting by Hieronymous Bosch...    The mass of the British infantry charges after the fleein Patriot militiamen... The Redcoat infantry grows disorderly as it runs... TARLETON AND THE BRITISH CAVALRY THUNDERS to the head of the Redcoats, closing in on the fleeing Patriots.  The cavalry swords are drawn and raised for a slaughter...

dialogues.speaker: THEN SUDDENLY
dialogues.text: Stepping into view from behind a low, grass covered rise, a SOLID LINE OF BLUE APPEARS, rock solid... It open up, allowing the fleeing Patriots to pass through it like water... then it closes again, becoming a solid blue wall...

dialogues.speaker: MARION, HIS MEN AND THE ENTIRE MASS OF FLEEING MILITIA
dialogues.text: STOPS DEAD, turns and joins the blue American line... A flurry of orders, then the BLUE WALL ERUPTS WITH A VOLLEY of musket fire that stops the disorderly British advance in its tracks... Hundreds of Redcoats fall instantly... Hundreds of Green Dragoons and their horses fall with them... The effect of the volley is devastating...' The American timing is perfect... Again, the amount of SMOKE is astonishing... visibility drops to less than twenty feet in most places... Drifting smoke opens up glimpses of the battle here and there but it is primarily a battle of sound... Men simply follow the men in front of them... The Blue Continentals advance in an orderly manner from both flanks onto the Redcoats, trapping them... The Redcoats try to flee... Fighting small, gathered holding actions... MARION FIRES one of his pistols... Draws his sword... Slashes downward... killing one Redcoat after another... No remorse, no hesitation, no pity... A relentless, simple battle... Slashing through the Redcoat infantry... His sword sinks into the stock of an upraised British musket and is pulled from his hands... Marion quickly kills the Redcoat with his pistol...

dialogues.speaker: TARLETON...
dialogues.text: Marion freezes... his eyes locked on Tarleton who is fighting a pitched battle, making his way toward the perimeter of the field, trying to escape back to the British lines... Seeing nothing but Tarleton, Marion hurriedly tears open his weapons pouch and pulls out one of the bullets made from Thomas' lead soldiers... As he loads the pistol, his eyes still trained on Tarleton, Dalton runs up in the chaos...

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Marion finishes reloading... distracted he turns to Dalto for an instant...

dialogues.speaker: OUR LINE IS FALTERING...
dialogues.text: Marion takes a quick glance at the Continental line, seeing... Scott, Rev. Oliver, Abner and a dozen more of his men, in the middle of a confused battle, with a larger mass of Redcoats who are advancing through the broken Continental line... MARION IS TORN... He looks to Tarleton, seeing him distracted, vulnerable but too distant a target for the pistol... Then Marion looks to Rev. Oliver and the others... Dalton can't wait... he runs off... Marion wavers... Then he takes a last look at Tarleton and heads off to help the faltering Patriots... TARLETON sees the movement of Marion and his men and sees Marion himself, his back exposed... AT THE PATRIOT LINE... Marion, Dalton and two dozen other militia cavalrymen arrive at the same time, beating back the Redcoats... As blue-uniformed Continentals reform the line, FIRING AT THE FALTERING REDCOATS... TARLETON sees Marion and fights his way toward him... Marion is oblivious, concentrating on holding the America line... Tarleton mounts a terrified, riderless horses, draws his sword and gallops back toward the British lines, on a pat that takes him directly past Marion... Tarleton gets closer... raises his sword... slashes... Marion catches the flash of the blade out of the corner o his eye... Diverts the blow, knocking Tarleton from the mount... Tarleton hits the ground... Marion draws his pistol, abou to fire at Tarleton... Tarleton KICKS OUT, knocking the pistol from Marion's hand... Tarleton GRABS HIS SWORD, SLASHES AT MARION who dodges th blow... Tarleton advances... Marion scrambles back, then rises... Marion grabs a BROKEN CAVALRY LANCE and FENDS OFF REPEATE BLOWS from Tarleton's SWORD... Then Marion sees his pistol, loaded with a bullet from Thomas' lead soldiers, lying on the ground... Marion makes his way toward the weapon... still BLOCKING BLOWS from Tarleton's sword... Marion focuses on the pistol... leaving himself exposed.. Tarleton sees the OPENING... MOVES ON MARION... TARLETON RAISES HIS SWORD, about to deliver the killing blow... Marion dives... GRABS HIS PISTOL... FIRES... KILLING TARLETON WITH A SHOT TO THE CHEST... Marion, stunned, exhausted and surprised to be alive, watches Tarleton fall... Marion stands over Tarleton's body and gives himself a moment of bitter triumph, then he turns back to the battl at hand... Marion picks up Tarleton's sword and runs to the AMERICAN LINE which stiffens as Dalton and Rev. Oliver are joined by Marion and a dozen other Patriots... The blue-uniformed Continentals reform their line... Marion looks back toward Tarleton but finds that his body along with the place and the moment of his death, has disappeared into the smoke of the battle... Marion and his men fight on... then, Redcoats start fleeing the field... First one Redcoat at a time... then more and more...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next day.  Silence.  The battlefield, as far as the eye can see, is covered with the debris of war, dead men and scattered weapons. The British have retreated back behind their defenses but have left many of their men on the field. The Patriots, regulars and militia, wait behind their barricades. Then, a single figure appears on one of the British parapets.  A DRUMMER BOY, no more than ten-years-old. Behind him, a single British officer. They boy begins to beat the drum.  The officer raises a white flag. In the American lines, the men see the flag.  Some call out, some cheer, some laugh, most, among them MARION, simply take a deep breath.  It's finally over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A massive ceremony, carefully orchestrated, laid out on the cleaned up battlefield. Thousands of men, everyone in his place, as if well- directed actors in a grand theatrical performance. The French and American armies, fifteen thousand men between them, stand in perfect formation on either side o the field, forming an avenue for the British army which marches out of it's fortification. At the head of the avenue, WASHINGTON AND HIS STAFF stand waiting. A musical band of Continentals, thirty men strong, loudly plays a tune, "The World Turned Upside Down," a jaunty British air with a melancholy undercurrent. CORNWALLIS marches with his officers, eyes straight ahead covering his agony as best he can. As he walks along the avenue he passes the remnants of th South Carolina militia. MARION, standing with Dalton, Rev. Oliver, Abner, Scott and the rest of his surviving men sees Cornwallis pass... CORNWALLIS glances over, noting what unit they are by a tattered battle standard that flies over them.  It's only a glance and he DOESN'T PICK OUT MARION, who is just one man among the many...

dialogues.speaker: AT THE HEAD OF THE AVENUE
dialogues.text: Cornwallis reaches Washington.  They exchange unheard formal greetings. Cornwallis, DRAWS HIS SWORD AND HANDS IT TO WASHINGTON... FIFTEEN THOUSAND MEN, American and French, RAISE THEIR VOICES in a CHEER OF ASTONISHING VOLUME... With every other pair of eyes directed toward the ceremon between Washington and Cornwallis, MARION quietly and unnoticed, slips out the back of the formation and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The surrender ceremony continues.  Marion, on the fringe of the field, finishes saddling his horses and prepares t leave.  LEE walks out of the crowd and joins him.  They lock eyes for a moment, then Marion mounts up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Francis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Harry. Marion reaches down.  They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And congratulations on the birth of your son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  Maybe all of this will buy him some peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope so. As Marion starts to ride off, he reins back and stops, speaking back to Lee over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your son, what did you name him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert.  Robert E. Lee. Marion smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A good name for a farmer. Lee nods.  Marion rides off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion's children and Charlotte sit by the river.  Samuel sits on the lookout ledge with his musket.  Suddenly he stands, looking out, seeing something. Charlotte and the others notice.  They're worried.  Then they see Samuel throw down his musket and tear down the path, running as fast as he can, tumbling, then regaining his feet... Charlotte and the others know who's coming... The children take off running after Samuel... Racing toward the road... Charlotte hurries after them... AND THEN THEY SEE HIM... MARION, riding at a full gallop... The children cry out with tears of joy... MARION see Susan... He gallops toward her... LEANS OVER... Without slowing, he SWOOPS HER UP into the saddle... She wraps herself around him... He reins back, stops and dismounts, just as the other children reach him... They throw themselves into his arms... embracing him... Charlotte hurries up behind them... She and Marion lock eyes and he is enveloped by the hugs of his children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Summer.  The apple tree at the top of the hill is covered with apples. Marion's house is partially rebuilt and habitable.  The workshop is already completed. MARION'S CHILDREN, Nathan, Samuel, Margaret and William, play in the tall grass in front of the house with the two GREAT DANES. CHARLOTTE sits on the front porch, NURSING AN INFANT. MARION walks out of his workshop, trailed by Susan.  He carries a just-completed rocking chair. The chair is a work of art, thin and light, a spider-web of perfectly turned wood, no nails, no glue. He steps onto the porch next to Charlotte and places the rocking chair next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two pounds, fourteen ounces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovely. He smiles and make a minute adjustment in the chair's position.  Then he sits down, settles back and begins rocking.  Not a creak. Marion and Charlotte watch Susan run out of the yard, calling as she joins the other children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait for me... As the CAMERA CRANES UP, Marion and Charlotte disappear beneath the overhang of the porch roof.  Suddenly, the SOUND OF A CRASH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damnation! The CAMERA CONTINUES TO CRANE UP as Marion walks off the porch, crosses the yard and enters his workshop.  A momen later, the SOUND OF MARION'S LATHE RISES.
